review_title: The song of a bamboo forest
review_content:
I'm a haiku lover: so simple to read, very difficult to write, disarmingly innocent. Here there is few room for interpretation: it's all clear from the beginning. This perfume celebrates silence or, maybe, the song of a bamboo forest. The opening is pure, citrusy bergamot with just a touch of rhubarb to give a bitter touch. The evolution of Amai Arashyiama plays with your imagination: some green, very smooth and woody note contribute to create a bamboo accord, sweetened by sugar and bamboo milk. As the fragrance dries down, the vertical structure of this bamboo forest invites your soul to elevation: another accord, this time a sacred one...incense. Defilitely not a liturgical one but more of a resinous, traditional frankincense smoke.
So easy to wear, the fragrance is not overwhelming and the projecetion is quite intimate (which to me is a plus!)

Olivier Pescheux created many best-selling fragrances, for example "1 Million for Man" for Paco Rabanne, "Iris Noir" and "Voile d'Ambre" for Yves Rocher or "Feérie" for van Cleef&Arpels. But he also did many "niche" scents for Diptyque. "Let's move" is a fragrance Pescheux composed for Benetton in 2012 and it's probably not going to become a blockbuster. Why? I guess it's too light and fresh and the formula is too commonplace. Up front we have citrus&pepper, followed by lavender&cedar. Tonka&vanilla smooth down the edges with their customary softness. "Let's move" is a very open and unpretentious scent, but it will probably not manage to insinuate itself into classic male cologne status. Not modern enough, not sexy enough, too quiet. But quite likeable.

I completely in love with the scent of this fragrance the rosemary and the bergamot in the opening are great Start in dry down it's going darker with the woody notes and leather joining. It is very similar to amouage interlude black iris . Maybe more fresh in the opening.
Scent 9/10
Performance 8/10
Giving me 2 hours of projection and 7 to 8 hours of staying on the clothes and maybe 3 hours on the skin

review_title: This is everything that was missing in the original in my opinion
review_content: I always felt like such a weirdo, when the original Libre wasn't my fav, I didn't hate it, it just wasn't me. Even the intense one. I am not the biggest vanilla girl, but something about this is just so well balanced. It smells expensive and floral and not heavy. The bottle is stunning oh my days it is gorg and i like this perfume a lot girl.

I was very curious about this new flanker in the beautiful bottle.

The typical Libre DNA is recognizable here as well, just significantly simplified.
The orange blossom has been toned down considerably, and the lavender is also much more restrained than in the predecessors.

During the first half hour, Libre Vanille Couture evokes the least from all the flankers in the series for me.
Familiar yet different, it feels a bit too arbitrary. Hm...

Once the opening settles, the new promised twist becomes apparent.
A vanilla that beautifully shifts between soft sweet and warm soft.

I don't catch any rum in my nose.
Too bad, I could have imagined a well-crafted boozy touch as an exciting variant for cold winter evenings and fancy occasions.
On the other hand, Libre Vanille Couture thus avoids drifting into the more gourmand territory and can maintain the more mature aura of its predecessors.

Overall, the fragrance becomes significantly more harmonious from this point on, gaining a snug quality that I can particularly envision for the colder months.

So, is it a new candidate for purchase?
I love the Libre line mainly for its rather "edgy" DNA, the interplay of cool and warm, bossy and feminine.

This somewhat gets lost in "Libre Vanille Couture | Yves Saint Laurent," which is why the fragrance will probably not replace my favorite variant "Libre Le Parfum | Yves Saint Laurent," which it actually comes closest to for me.

For anyone who already has one of its sisters in their closet, it’s probably not a revelation, but still nicely done and worth a test.
Even those who found the predecessors perhaps too harsh might find happiness with this toned-down version.

Do I really still need you? I thought to myself after I heard about the release. I see the bottle .. read the notes .. YES, my Libre collection is probably going to get bigger! Ordered online from Paris right away .. a few days later it was there and I got to smell it for the first time .. once again a pricey blind buy. It was worth it! The original Libre is still there although for me it’s more the Libre Le Parfum but with such a dreamy vanilla drydown .. heavenly! I am in love! By the way, I don't perceive anything in the rum.

Here you initially get the original Libre DNA - lavender, orange blossom, and jasmine combined with vanilla - so nothing new at first.

However, the scent is distinctly warmer and more vanillic from the very beginning (and of course throughout its entire development). It strongly reminds me of the Libre Le Parfum variant, but it is actually "different" in its vanilla. The listed candy vanilla shines through wonderfully here. An authentic, slightly earthy, and perhaps even minimally animalistic vanilla. So definitely not a mundane baking vanilla or something similar. I find the twist very exciting. However, I don't get the listed rum or any other boozy note.

The bottle is also a dream and a "must-have" for Libre collectors and lovers. The limited edition makes it particularly appealing.

Anyone who generally likes Libre and is not averse to vanilla should definitely give it a try. But please make sure to test it on the skin and give the scent a little time. The scent on the test strip was not remotely like it was on my skin even after several hours.

Wow.. the appearance is already a highlight, and the scent even more so! At first, I was a bit hesitant due to the price, but my eyes simply made the decision. It feels significantly more sensual than its predecessors. I imagine it being perfect for winter, with an elegant coat, red lips, and a tightly pulled-back ponytail on a date.. After over 60 fragrances, I still don't have a clear favorite in the number 1 spot… maybe this will be it? Absolute recommendation, and perfect for gifting.

Libre is unfortunately not my line. I’ve tried them all, and somehow the lavender note doesn’t resonate with me here. Only the Libre EAU DE PARFUM INTENSE was the warmest for me.

It's a shame that this one is limited. I would immediately add it to my collection after just one test! The vanilla is more dominant here than the lavender, which makes it interesting for me, and the rum here... It won me over right away!

But limited, and I really don’t like that! I don’t like a love that’s limited in time.

But maybe it will eventually be added to the permanent collection.
It would definitely be the most beautiful in the line.
I also like the vanilla note from "Black Opium Le Parfum | Yves Saint Laurent," and this is exactly it here!
Divine

The Moomins - friendly, troll-like mythical creatures with a hippopotamus-like shape - were not entirely unknown to me from my childhood, but apparently I was a bit too old for such series when they became more prominent on German television in the late 70s. I only just learned that the first books were written and illustrated by the Finnish/Swedish author Tove Jansson as early as the 1940s. The virtual home of the Moomins in the far north seems to have also inspired the Moomin perfume series by Demeter (alongside “Finnish Snowfield,” there’s also “Icelandic Aurora” and “Norwegian Wood”).

“Finnish Snowfield” is, in my opinion, a delicate, light floral scent with hints of lemon-juice-spiced herbal tea. The association with a bright sun shining over a powdery snowfield seems quite fitting to me, but I also can’t help but think of the first spring flowers waiting for their moment to emerge beneath the snow. Therefore, for me, it’s a perfume for the waning winter.
Moderate longevity, but at least it’s a perfume that is suitable for wearing and not just for “bringing to mind” certain scent images.

I got a dabber bottle in the Winter and I wasn't impressed. It smelled generic and fruity with some fresh notes but I didn't love it. I didn't even like it, it was SO boring. The bottle was still pretty so I kept it on my desk at work for decoration. Now that Spring as come around, so have I. I went to work perfume-naked and reached for my Pretty Pink for the first time in months. Today it's 50-65F and sunny and for the first time this scent makes sense. Pretty Pink is a summer cocktail that brings freshness for the fruit lovers. The citrus, basil, and Bellini notes stand out the most, with the floral middle notes blending everything together. The ambery, musky base is familiar and safe. If you typically love fruity florals and want something that's a little bit fresher and greener, but still in your comfort zone, Pretty Pink will get you through the warm weather, and look cute on your vanity for the rest of the year.

We already know not to judge a book by its cover, but never judge a fragrance by its bottle! Not only the bottle, but the name of this perfume as well evoke something hyper-feminine, sugary sweet, and maybe tropical or red fruits. Instead, this is citrusy, fresh, and shockingly... unisex? So any guy that is brave enough to have a fragrance that looks like this, I think it might be worth a try. But to be honest, it doesn't seem like that unique of a fragrance, so if the bottle bothers you, you can probably find something a little less... ostentatious that gives you the same effect.

Anna Sui, you really know how to put some simple ass fragrances in extremely fancy bottles. And damn it, I'm gonna keep buying them until I have all those bottles... I'll just refill them with more interesting (or at least more fitting) fragrances.

... standing in a hot day in the middle of the garden among the blooming flowers and inhaling their scents along with the freshness of the damp grass and the woods of the surrounding trees. I hold my coffee cup, sipping it enjoyably while I glide my bare feet over the grass. This is how every morning should start.

When applying this fragrance, the nose first encounters the green of the cypress, mixed with the slightly sharp freshness of ginger. A spicy and floral accord quickly follows. The woods that join at the end make the perfume dry and woody, giving it a masculine touch.

Here we have a beautiful fresh woody aquatic scent that can be worn by any age group. On warm and hot days, I see this as a great all-rounder for daytime wear that can be worn anytime and anywhere. The scent is masculine and is not necessarily for the ladies, but can certainly be tried, as perfumes smell different on every skin.

Anyone who enjoys a fresh woody aquatic masculine fragrance will find this quite suitable, and at a very good price.

review_title: So beautiful yet underrated! Summer on the skin.
review_content:
In search of a new summer fragrance that suits me, I tried many perfumes. I stumbled upon this bottle and honestly didn't think much of it at first. It fits perfectly within a small budget but can easily compete with designer scents. I sprayed it on my arm and let myself be surprised:

The opening starts off beautifully citrusy and fresh. The citrus note isn't listed, but you can definitely smell it. However, the zesty opening fades away, transitioning into an iced tea vibe. Not peach or lemon, but a very unique, homemade iced tea that you would love to order on a warm summer day. The scent becomes a bit sweeter and smoother like an iced tea. At this point, you can really notice the similarity to YSL La Nuit de L'Homme.
As the summer day turns into a summer evening, the fragrance also shifts in that direction. It leaves behind a creamy, sweet scent reminiscent of a lemon muffin.

At this point, I have to mention the longevity. Unfortunately, it isn't very good, which is why I tend to spray it on multiple times a day because it’s just so enjoyable. You want to have it around you all the time and experience the evolution of the scent again and again.
That's why I carry it in a small mini atomizer to-go and sometimes reapply. At this price, that's also manageable without putting a strain on the wallet.

All in all, great scent, very underrated, and perfect for summer like an iced tea full of ice cubes. Highly recommended, and during the sale, you can get the 30 ml bottle for very little money.

In my eyes, a completely overlooked freshie. I love the scent and have been wearing it almost daily for some time now. It's just very nice and fresh, but still a bit different from the others. The scent has replaced 360 Red by Perry Ellis for me as a feel-good, no-think fragrance. Sillage and longevity are top-notch for this category. Additionally, I find the bottle an absolute eye-catcher. Anyone looking for a new fresh scent should definitely give this one a chance.

I (27F) received Exceptional Parfums' Simply Belle as a free sample dabber and fell in love with it on first sniff. It has checked all the boxes for me - except one.

It is bright, fresh, and uplifting without being overly juicy or juvenile. For me, it is the perfect ratio of floral to citrus, without one overpowering the other, nor blending so much that it smells overripe or sharp. I appreciate its simple and straightforward scent, as complex and wood-based blends gives me a headache. Its drydown melds into a sort of youthful, musky skin scent on me, still keeping that same floral-citrus blend with no specific notes screaming out.

I ordered this perfume in the winter and have been wearing it even in colder months, but it would definitely fall under a spring and summer scent. I could wear this any time of the day, but would envision it more of a refreshing morning and afternoon scent.

The one disappointment and only box it does not check is its longevity. It disappears after the first hour on my skin, which is quite disappointing for an EDP. On clothes, it lasts around two to three hours. There is almost no sillage after the first half hour, so on the positive side, it is safe for the office. Its market price is reasonable, so I don't feel guilty generously spraying it around like an EDT. I am currently trying different methods in hopes of prolonging its scent on me.

All in all, this would 100% be my signature scent if the longevity was better.

I was given a bottle of Simply Belle to try it out. It’s not impressive. The floral notes don’t stand out singularly. I can make out Lily of the valley and Waterlily only. The rest falls together into a soup. At the end there’s a bit of musk, but overall this perfume doesn’t change much over time.
The scent is unappealing to me. It could be my personal chemistry that doesn’t boost the perfume. I don’t know.

The sillage is about 18 inches tops, longevity blessedly short. I don’t know how much it is new, but I wouldn’t buy it for myself. Perhaps a teenage girl might enjoy it.

I do not understand the mediocre rating of this perfume, I think it is a very interesting fragrance. On my skin it turns out a little soapy jasmine at first and then the fragrance becomes very powdery, as if it could be crumbled with your fingers. At the same time I find it green but not fresh: it is like the green of leaves that are already very dry, like they are aged or tanned by the sun. I am not one of aromas with a floral predominance, but I really like this one from Rania J.

review_title: a 180 from A La Nuit and other creamy indolic jasmines
review_content: The bergamot hits at the opening and remains quite persistent on me. The musk, sandalwood and jasmine play supporting roles in this on my skin. The heliotrope gives this scent a powdery vibe, somewhat akin to the powder in YSL's Paris. It also has a similar bright sparkling nature, like in old bottles of Yvresse/Champagne. The sillage and longevity are good, about a foot from the body and longevity over four hours so far and maintaining the sillage. I find the quality good with no synthetic notes apparent. However this is more of a green/citrus scent and not so much a jasmine oriented scent. It would be on the other end of the spectrum from creamy jasmines like Serge Lutens' A la nuit.

review_title: If only it were just Jasmine....
review_content:
I love the scent of pure, clean, heavy jasmine on a summer night. The most beautiful jasmine I experienced was in Tunisia. I think Egyptian jasmine, as indicated in the pyramid, is experienced similarly. I was all the more excited to test Jasmine Kâma and all the more disappointed by the result.

Jasmine as the theme of a fragrance may tolerate a leading top note to avoid coming on too strong. But everything else that has been added around Jasmine Kâma disturbs and distorts the animalistic heaviness of jasmine and robs the fragrance of the vibrant mood it is otherwise capable of evoking. This feels irritating and makes the scent simply loud and oppressive.

Patchouli and woods unnecessarily roughen the otherwise oily-silky smoothness, heliotrope is a lovely scent on its own with its friendly and rather harmless sweetness, but it does not fit at all with jasmine, and vanilla seems to be indispensable and is used almost inflationarily in my opinion. The base is quite pretty on its own, but for me it feels like it was accidentally added.

The name of the perfume had led me to expect a classic soliflore. But such a note must be allowed to stand on its own. Similar to a solitaire as a piece of jewelry, it cannot tolerate any other decorative embellishments, and thus, in my opinion, the jasmine in this fragrance has been robbed of its beauty.

I waited until the last moment to test Jasmin Kâma, as I suspected a true floral monster with such a perfume name.

I was right with my assumption!

Jasmin Kâma should be called Jasmine Anesthesia for me!

I can't speak of a top and heart note with this fragrance, as aside from a soapy, animalistic jasmine note, I can't perceive anything else for hours.
What surprises me, however, is that despite the numbing intensity, I never felt uneasy or had a headache at any time.

Only after an eternity does the floral anesthesia fade, leaving a truly pleasant daze in the form of a really beautiful base note.

The jasmine then submits to a soft, pleasantly sweet accord, which nearly makes the strains of the floral blast fade into oblivion. But only nearly!

Aside from the base accord, the sillage is expansive, and it will probably not surprise anyone that the longevity is also quite impressive. On me, Jasmin Kâma lasted noticeably until the next shower, and even after that, I could still perceive a faint trace of it.

Those who, like me, do not particularly enjoy overly floral fragrances should be a bit more cautious with the dosage when testing Jasmin Kâma. However, jasmine lovers will surely get their money's worth here.

review_title: A pink fluffy cloud of muskus decorated with red berries
review_content: "Pavlova" is a pink fluffy cloud of transparent muskus decorated with red berries. Not the smell of the "Pavlova" dessert itself, but a sensual representation of it. Strawberry juice, an echo of "Strawberry in cream" (a popular candy from the USSR times) and a layer of sweet and sour jam from red berries. The muskus cloud here is not something I smell. I rather feel its presence as a sense of transparent fullness within the smell. A scene for the berries to play their role. It also remember similar musks as a feeling of pink mist from some aquarel-like perfumes of roses and peonies. An lovely light and airy fragrance...

Nina Ricci has been around for quite some time and she's not exactly know for creating masculine fragrances but the ones that she HAS made have all been very very good and Memoire D'Homme is no different. This nuclear sized spice rack acts like something right out of the 80s with great longevity and high quality. Nina Ricci brings it home and I wear it sparingly as it's not a casual everyday fragrance. The winter is when it behaves the best as the spicy woody notes permeate through the cold just like a hot knife through butter.

At 1st the beginning is kind of raunchy as the Licorice note sticks to your skin like glue but as time passes the other notes start to make their presence known throughout. I will say this though if you're not a fan of licorice then you probably will not care very much for this however. As for myself the Licorice note is not only nice but very necessary because that's the one note that makes it's presence clear. 4 or 5 sprays is all you'll need to get you through the day and most of the night. The other big players are Ginger, Nutmeg, Grapefruit, Pomelo, Vetiver, Amber, Cedar, Opoponax, Myrrh, Ambergris and Musk. As you can see this fragrance uses major league masculine notes and anyone within a few feet of you will know there's a true MAN in your midst. I can't say enough about it except try it for yourself.

Not the rule, but when you see a house with a lot of perfumes and only the very few are masculine (at least marketed at) then you get the impression that some real effort focus and time went down to create these special ones. The one I owned for quite some time and really liked was Memoire d'Homme.

Upon spraying you get the feeling that this is your typical men's cologne but it is not! You get a citrusy initial bang taking up almost the entire frame, but some nutmeg, ginger and definitely licorice are photobombing in the background.

The licorice... I got really acquainted with this note thanks to my partner's black soft licorice caramels she was stuffing my mouth with in the winter. In this composition the licorice is done right with a balanced feel to it thanks to grapefruit in the beginning and then the nutmeg. The ginger has a sparkling role keeping the structure somehow fresh.

And then there is the amazing woody semi sweet drydown that keeps going for hours on skin, not to mention its persistence on clothes. For me this is where this scent really shines. Like staring down at a pine(?) forest from a higher point with the traces of a licorice caramel you were torturing in your mouth to melt for 10 minutes. Great stuff people.

I am keeping the "oh my god!! why did you discontinue such a wonderful underatted superfantastic scent?!?!?" for some other time or scent...

Screw it...

oh my god!! why did you discontinue such a wonderful underatted superfantastic scent?!?!?

Not a fan. Many compare this to one of my favorite scents, Terre d'Hermes, but I really don't see much of the comparison... On my skin, this is all about licorice, nutmeg and cedar after the initial grapefruit top note. The cedar being the main similarity between the two scents to me. The grapefruit top note here is nice, but it lasts for just a few seconds and is gone, leaving just the licorice behind; transitioning to the nutmeg and cedar notes. I regret my blind buy of this one and have gave away my bottle with no regrets. Memoire d'Homme gets a below average rating of 2 stars out of 5 and an "avoid" recommendation.

here is my first comment :-)

I received this fragrance as a gift about 4 years ago...

Unfortunately, my taste was completely missed!

The base notes might not be bad, but it seems to me that everything has just been mixed together at will. What ultimately comes out is a sweet - fruity mixture...

For anyone who, like me, prefers woody / leathery / spicy fragrances, this is definitely not suitable!

review_title: Lots of blue notes - From the sight of a blind
review_content:
Oxford by roberto Ugolini ( Instagram: @roberto_ugolini_bespoke_shoes ; @the_nose_behind )
Oxford was the first fragrance that I bought from the house of Roberto Ugoline, completely "blind", I have relied completely on the reviews in
the social media channels. I can imagine that someone else also make it this way, but with a perfume in the high-price segment of more than 200 € not normality. But I must admit without reservation that I was not disappointed!

The first spray envelops me with pure freshness, citrus and grapefruit, a nice spicy peppery note rounds off the first impression. After some time, the very fresh opening evaporates and the spice comes through very well tuned,
my compliments to the perfumer! Often I personally feel the pepper note too extreme, here is the necessary balance for me. The spicy tension remains very long, until finally after some time woods join in and give the fragrance a
great finish. The woody aroma in combination with a very slight sweetness is a real dream. | In my head immediately manifest themselves some blue tones, which gradually reach a great homogeneity, a brief touch of purple is
also present. The pepper I perceive not as a color, but rather as many small rough balls that spread in my yet very sensitive nose. Pleasant, very pleasant. The base I perceive as a very dark beige, I think it is due to the
sandalwood and the slight sweetness that round out this great finish.
This fragrance is universally wearable, office, date or even funeral, you can't go wrong with oxford

---
If you like my way to discribe scents just follow me on Instagram :-)
https://www.instagram.com/blind.smell.bk/

Oxford was the first fragrance created for Roberto Ugolini. Meant to be a business- and office-friendly scent, it's nice and masculine with its pepper and grapefruit opening and heart. I love it and use it on a weekly rotation especially if I'm meeting clients for work.

I've used this for a job interview in the past and for plenty of meetings, paired of course with Oxford dress shoes. It's a nice and fairly heavy citric-spicy combination. This is the fragrance that gave me love for the grapefruit aroma.

Associated with cleanliness: dressed, shaved, ready for business. Maybe a tie with the odd pattern to keep things fun, that's up to the wearer. This is what I use Oxford for, anyway. However, despite the formality that accompanies the Oxford shoe that this fragrance is named after, this is still a versatile scent for the man who might not choose to wear a suit but still finds himself in more business-forward occasions.

Strong performance. I used three sprays on my first ever wear and felt it was too much. This juice lasts me eight or nine solid hours.

This is a purely masculine fragrance to my perception, but likely due to the scenarios in which I personally use it.

The only thing I would change would be to swap the bottle colors with Derby. Usually, (the more formal) Oxford shoes are black and (the more casual) Derbies are brown, so to me it would make more sense to imitate this through the bottle colors. Just a geek's two cents! :)

review_title: What an old school man would smell like
review_content: Think of a dark fragrance that got a lot of character to it but presented in a very fresh, woody but also likeable and airy way. Definietly a masculin fragrance that shouts ' I have got my shit together' but in a very elegant way. Easy to pull off. For me personally, an everyday fragrance. Can pull this off with a Tuxedo but also with a tank top. Thats how versatile this is! Projection is moderate to skin scent but creates a nice bubble around you where everybody notices the fragrance!

Since early morning, I had been tracking the DHL vehicle, which according to the app was only 10 stops away from me. How long would it take to deliver 10 packages? Now I know, it took almost 3 hours and that nearly drove me crazy.

Normally, I'm not an impatient person, but when I mentally already have my package in hand, it drives me insane. Minute by minute, I wondered if the DHL vehicle might have been involved in an accident, in which café the driver was taking a break, if he might have been invited in by a lonely housewife, or if he was taking a nap in some poorly visible parking lot.

But then I saw the yellow van with the highly visible red DHL stickers from afar. I rushed out of my apartment, down the stairs, and to the front door, even before the vehicle had come to a stop.

The friendly delivery driver handed me a black package. The sender was Kai Porten, whose promotion for Perfume Day I took advantage of to order two fragrances from Roberto Ugolini, which he had discounted by 20%. Besides that, I had ordered a discovery set with the fragrances from Schwarzlose Berlin, but that's just a side note, as I actually want to talk about one of the two Roberto Ugolinis, namely the Oxford. Nevertheless, I want to take a moment to thank Kai Porten, who kindly included a 50 ML tester of the fragrance "Treffpunkt 8 Uhr" from Schwarzlose Berlin in the package. As influencers like to say: "Shoutout to Kai, you're totally cool, man. Thank you!"

So, now to the Oxford. The bottle is like all bottles from Roberto Ugolini. They all look the same, differing only in color. I now own 5 of them. The Oxford bottle is transparent brown, feels heavy in hand, and conveys to me, like its brothers, a decent quality. Personally, I also appreciate the horn caps. I once had the fun of weighing the bottle. It settled at 302 grams. Compared to other bottles, it is rather light, but its tactile feel suggests otherwise.

However, this shouldn't be a dealbreaker for a perfume. The packaging of Ugolini fragrances far surpasses many others by miles.

A first tentative spray on my forearm. I probably should have waited, but I was really curious. After all, this was a blind purchase. Many others, even here in this community, didn't make the decision to buy this fragrance for me, but at least they strongly endorsed it. There was often talk of a certain elegance, of a fragrance for the older gentleman (and at 59, I undoubtedly fit that description), of a fragrance for the self-assured gentleman. While I don't see myself as an elegant gentleman, I am fundamentally very interested in characteristics that underline such attributes. This includes stylish clothing, also expensive handmade shoes, and indeed fragrances like the Oxford from Roberto Ugolini.

In fact, I come to the conclusion that this fragrance is exactly what has been described in various reviews here and elsewhere. After the first few seconds, I wasn't sure what exactly I was smelling, but it quickly split into a not too aggressive citrus note and a distinctly recognizable pepper note. I also detect the rose after just a few moments. I find the beginning of the fragrance development to be exceptionally pleasant. A cloud surrounds my head, and indeed the elegance, the grooming, the self-assurance of a well and expensively dressed older gentleman, who is quite aware of his effect on others, becomes palpable for me.

This fragrance combination lasts - I would estimate - a good hour and then develops into woody notes. They smell good too, but I feel the need to re-spray because I just don’t want that cloud to dissipate. But I suppose I have to endure that; after all, I can't refresh it every hour.
In short, although the pepper and rose recede a bit to let the woody notes take the lead, the fragrance loses none of its elegance. It was beautiful, it is beautiful, and it remains beautiful until it becomes barely detectable on my skin after about 8 hours, but that is far from bad.

So, this blind purchase ends with a happy ending. I can unreservedly recommend this fragrance, at least for a more mature gentleman. From my perspective, it's definitely not for women; that's my opinion. Oxford is more of a subtle fragrance, but that is certainly in line with its wearer's intent. It makes sense in the office, but it is also definitely suitable for dining out, for cocktail bars, and for larger family celebrations, etc. I, for one, am glad to have it.

Dear perfume lovers,
as this is my first review, I would like to ask for your understanding.

This perfume lives up to its name. I do not mean to say that it smells like leather or a worn shoe.
Rather, it is the association and presence that the perfume and the gentleman's shoe share - the classic gentleman.
Elegant, classic, versatile, unobtrusive, and yet striking.
But how can an unobtrusive perfume that smells of grapefruit, pepper, and wood still be so noticeable? Precisely because of its timeless elegance, which is rarely found today.
An elegance that only a gentleman can exude.

A scent that is simply noticeable when entering a room. Even though it has no ambitions to be loud and take center stage, this scent cannot be overlooked. Through class, charm, and its unobtrusive presence, one inevitably perceives this fragrance with great interest.

Anyone who has had the pleasure of meeting a true gentleman and conversing with him knows what I am talking about. His style, radiating class and elegance, and his character, full of charm and depth, inevitably entice one to engage in a long conversation with the respective gentleman and learn more about him and his life.
This is precisely what characterizes this wonderful scent by Roberto Ugolini.

When I spray Oxford, I immediately notice notes of grapefruit and pepper. The longer I wear it on my skin, the more pronounced the woody and resinous notes become. After about 5 hours, the scent becomes softer, and I detect a light hint of vanilla and earthy patchouli.
This scent can definitely not be called a sillage monster. In my opinion, that would be completely misplaced and would not do justice to a gentleman as I have described him.

Some recommend Oxford only for those aged 30 and above. I would like to disagree with that. It is a scent like a shoe. Wearable by anyone, if combined appropriately. Whether for leisure, office, or dinner; this scent is suitable for every situation and incredibly versatile. Those who wear this fragrance will be remembered for their unmistakable style.

Stylish and fragrant greetings,
Nico

review_title: The world reinvented? Not at all.
review_content: What a pity, I received this fragrance as a sample and was actually quite happy with the sample until I sprayed it. It smells almost exactly like Black Afgano by Nasomatto. This is definitely not a bad fragrance; I also really like the original and own it - but unfortunately, the creative effort here is very meager. However, one must give credit to the fragrance that the first...

A scent for fans of woody fragrances. Wonderful development and very good longevity on my skin.

Upon spraying, pepper, orange, and rose. After an hour, fantastic wood notes with a hint of vanilla. Great dry down and still noticeable on me the next morning. After three hours, it strongly reminds me of Terre EDP with a bit more vetiver.

Good craftsmanship from the shoemaker master from Italy! The all-rounder for any occasion for men over 40. Not a youthful scent.

review_title: Elegant and always suitable like a good Oxford shoe
review_content: I have been testing Oxford for a longer period now, and I can say right away. The scent lives up to its name; it is simply always suitable for both a casual linen shirt and a tuxedo. Oxford is like its namesake, always fitting for any occasion. At first, I was a bit hesitant and struggled with whether I should test Oxford, as I somehow always had the fear that there might be leather in it, which I absolutely do not like in perfume. Fortunately, Oxford has no leather note, which relieved me greatly. Right after spraying, the freshness of grapefruit comes to the fore, complemented immediately by spicy and bitter notes. I particularly smell pepper, cedarwood, and something sweet, which probably comes from the sandalwood and vanilla note. I can't really detect the other notes, but that's not a problem because the notes I can perceive very well create a wonderful scent that simply fits in any weather. The exception might be above 35 degrees. Oxford is a very nice fresh, spicy, and slightly sweet scent that is truly very universal. However, I find the unisex classification not very fitting, as I can better imagine the scent on a man due to the combination of the spicy notes; also, the name Oxford evokes the association of a men's fragrance for me. I believe the scent deserves significantly better ratings, but unfortunately, the brand Roberto Ugolini is quite underrated. I recommend you test Oxford and give the fragrance some time.

The alarm rings - brush teeth - shower - do hair - put on Oxford and into the suit. My daily morning ritual.

Whether in meetings or on a "quiet" day in the office, Oxford always works for me.

It's all about the blend - citrus freshness, a bit of pepper, and wood without being intrusive, yet still noticeable to those around. After a while, for me, a hint of vanilla comes through with the woodiness, but without becoming overwhelming.

I would recommend the scent more for men; I wouldn’t perceive it as unisex. Age, in my opinion, is not a factor - as a 20-year-old student, I would have loved to wear it too.

I acquired this fragrance as a decant based on a recommendation from my colleague, and I was not impressed at all during the first wear. I quite liked the scent DNA, but I couldn't confirm that this fragrance lasts long.
Naturally, I was annoyed and disappointed, although I was happy that I had "only" gotten a decant, as a blind buy would have been much worse.
When I wanted to give it a second chance, I approached it without any prejudices:
I wore a suit and was scheduled for a business meeting.
I applied the fragrance only on my skin and NOT on my textile, as I have often experienced that less is sometimes more, and our noses tend to give in faster the more we apply. (Scent blindness)
Then, on a mild, cloudy day, as I stepped out of my house and got into my car, I was overwhelmed by love for this fragrance to the point that I didn't know what was happening.
Woody notes, paired with citrus and pepper. However, everything is very, very, very unobtrusive!
Sometimes you smell the fragrance, sometimes you don’t. People around you smell it sometimes, then again they don’t. The perfect variation for serious meetings in a suit. I absolutely cannot stand it when someone in the room smells so strongly of perfume that the entire room smells like that person. Many people ruin a scent for me this way. Can we already talk about a kind of scent abuse? Well… That’s why this fragrance is anything but loud, yet people notice it, and of course, so do I.
It goes so far that I can still smell this fragrance in the evening, but very discreetly, now and then :)
Since yesterday, I am a proud owner of this masterpiece and can truly say that it is my absolute favorite for the office!
Give it a second or even a third chance. You won’t regret it :)

Like the shoe from which Ugolini got his name, the fragrance is perfectly suited for special occasions. But even in everyday life, the Oxford rarely comes across as intrusive. In my opinion, it is a very good signature scent for a mature man. It feels more refined and has a good touch of elegance and complexity compared to the modern classic from Hermès. The Oxford has less freshness than Terre d'Hermès. The grapefruit disappears very quickly here, and the orange is similar to that in Hermès, but it plays a slightly smaller role in this case. As the fragrance develops, the Oxford becomes a bit heavier, woodier, and gains a slight sweetness from the vanilla, which is only subtle. I can't complain about the longevity and sillage. 8-10 hours are no problem on my skin. The projection of the fragrance is also very satisfactory. The sillage is strong and only starts to fade after several hours.

I found it while searching for an office scent that doesn’t smell like generic shower gel. I really enjoy wearing TDH (EDT and Pure Perfume), and since it is often associated with it, this was a blind buy that I do not regret.

It is quite different from TDH, with a strong dominating pepper and woods. TDH is consistently citrusy and fresh, while this one is citrusy and spicy. I wouldn’t say: If you have TDH, you don’t need this one anymore - rather, if you already have TDH, you need this one even more, as it interprets something similar in its own unique, slightly more potent, and truly beautiful way.

I find the longevity to be excellent; I was able to perceive the scent well for 12 hours today - it lasts better on clothes than on (my) skin, and I don’t quite understand how it only gets an 8.0 for longevity here. Also, regarding TDH: it definitely doesn’t achieve this longevity for me, as it fades after 6 hours, both EDT and Perfume. And that’s a good thing, as the difference between niche and designer should not only be recognized in the price but also in the quality and performance. This is the case here!

For me, Oxford has been my absolute favorite for the office for some time now. It lasts a long time but is not too overpowering.
Especially the woody drydown is very pleasing.

Initially, it has a slightly alcoholic note right after spraying, but that disappears relatively quickly. What remains is a very pleasant fresh woody note.

I still perceive the scent very intensely even after a long workday.

Here too, I don't really get the citrusy or in this case the orangey, grapefruit-like aspect at the beginning. For me, it is immediately woody, spicy, balsamic, and on such a fine level that it captivated me right away. It is currently my showcase student... which means I wear the Oxford the most and love it the most. Such a wonderfully warm, relaxing, yet lovely and inspiring...

The Oxford shoe as a British classic and Oxford as a breeding ground for a so-called stylish elite already hint at this popular fragrance: Herbert Stricker's Ugolini manufactory offers a typically complex scent experience with Oxford as a perfume, which elegantly and effortlessly fulfills its daily duty on its wearer and scores at all times. Always wearable, always understated, with a noticeable but never unpleasant presence.

Oxford starts off very fruity in the top note, the peppery heart note with rose geranium leaf brings spice, a slight sharpness, and invigorates the scent and is distinctly present, but never unpleasant (I tend to like pepper in perfumes rather rarely). The broad, beautifully woody, slightly smoky, somewhat vanillic, and earthy base carries Oxford for several hours and projects well, but does not overwhelm anyone. In the drydown, Oxford oddly has a slightly soapy finish and also faint hints of aftershave, but never unpleasant or too pronounced. This Ugolini is therefore rather something for men, but I would be quite interested in the scent on women...

Anyway: Oxford is actually suitable for any occasion; I can't think of a scenario where it wouldn't fit. Without thinking, I say: Spray on without a second thought! Moreover, it also has this optimistic undertone of: Enjoy your life and try to have fun and convey this good vibe to others.

A noble, elegant, understated scent with decent presence. Indeed, a gentleman's fragrance!

Hello dear Parfumo community, this is my very first review ever. I couldn't resist leaving a comment on this delicious scent. What can I say, I received my bottle today and I am thrilled. I read numerous reviews and watched videos about this fragrance, and I am simply speechless. Since many described it as being similar to Terre d’Hermes, I was tempted to make a...

I got Oxford because I wanted to treat myself for the office! And right from the first spray, I thought: wow, absolute bullseye!

It starts off so wonderfully spicy and is also somehow fresh! The combination of grapefruit and orange with the pepper is really fantastic. The woods in the base then ensure that the scent gets a solid structure. The woods, patchouli, and vanilla also make it very elegant, which fits very well for me in the office.

Sillage and longevity could be a bit better, but it is never intrusive or bothersome.

Decide for yourself.

…, who has been through a lot and has tried many things, wears Oxford by Roberto Ugolini - my first fragrance from this house. I find this scent is aimed at all established personalities who are responsible and trustworthy - thoroughly serious. Definitely over 35. It is worn by a man in a suit, not with sneakers but, as the name suggests, with stylish shoes. Definitely...

review_title: The Italian Black Afgano for the Office?
review_content: Roberto Ugolini takes his name from the classic men's shoe Oxford, and we can stick with the word classic, as it describes this fragrance very well. So we have a classic men's scent but with modern elements in its DNA, which I really like - as it doesn't smell as outdated as Terre d'Hermès, for example. (For many, it smells old, but not for everyone!) But how does the...

GREAT! An absolutely amazing fragrance. For me, the perfect signature scent. Less suitable for the club and high summer, but perfect in all other situations. The grapefruit is very prominent and is relatively quickly replaced by the pepper. In the base note, I perceive the vanilla very prominently, and the patchouli is also really noticeable! In my opinion, this is a scent...

First of all, a classification - I love Terre d'Hermes and wear it regularly on all occasions.

Now I wanted to try the much-praised Oxford and after the first sprays, I didn't know what to think. YES, Oxford is spicier at the beginning and doesn't come with such a bitter grapefruit, but otherwise, it really differs little from the aforementioned scent.
Of course, Terre d'Hermes eventually loses its power and you only have light resinous-woody notes LEFT, BUT does that justify the price difference?

Please don't get me wrong - I find Oxford very good and would claim that any man can wear this scent for almost any occasion.

The question that arises for me - do you need Oxford if you can have Terre d'Hermes?

“Oxford” by Roberto Ugolini is a work of art full of sensuality and sophistication. The perfect balance of floral and woody notes creates an aura of elegance and mystique that enchants the wearer.
The aromas are subtle and complex, making it an unforgettable fragrance experience. The scent itself exudes an aura of intelligence and knowledge, giving the wearer a sense of strength and self-confidence. “Oxford” by Roberto Ugolini is a masterpiece of perfumery and a must for anyone who appreciates refined fragrances.

What takes a long time... I've had my eye on the scent for a while, or rather, my nose through a sample. Until now, the pepper note has held me back from purchasing, as I confused it with synthetic scents. However, in the bottle I bought, this note is strangely no longer prominently noticeable. Or perhaps I have simply educated my nose through much "more challenging"...

review_title: Beautiful Woody Spice for Everyday Use
review_content:
This Roberto Ugolini definitely needs to be reviewed by me. A quite popular scent from this brand. Christian Carbonnel has certainly created a great fragrance for Roberto Ugolini that could be called an all-rounder. It combines several styles and is also not too heavy to wear. Many here refer to this scent as an office or everyday fragrance. You can definitely do that, but for me, it’s an all-rounder that can also work very well in the evening due to its woody-spicy DNA, which slightly leans towards "Gucci Intense Oud | Gucci." This one is a bit easier to wear than the Gucci, but you should definitely test it before buying. You get a soft woody scent with a pleasing spice. There’s also a citrus freshness active in the background that makes this fragrance extremely suitable for everyday use. It also has enough charm for the evening and definitely possesses great gentleman vibes.

In terms of pricing, this brand is quite fair, especially if you shop in stores with decent discounts. You can already get 100ml for under €150, which is absolutely fair for this quality. The fragrance comes in the usual orange Ugolini packaging. The bottle is pretty with this leather patch, and here the bottle comes in a cozy brown that matches the scent.
The fragrance already smells really elegant right after spraying. Even though the top notes of grapefruit and orange suggest a very fresh opening, this creation is only conditionally fresh, as the woody-spicy notes are present from the very beginning and provide beautiful vibes that are particularly good on autumn days. Styrax from the base also sets in early and adds a slightly balsamic-resinous note that brings some warmth. Pepper and a gentle geranium also come through, giving it a nice soft spice. Wood comes from sandalwood and cedarwood, offering a great combination that impresses here. Vetiver makes this creation somewhat classic and quite elegant. Patchouli adds a bit of edgy and slightly earthy vibes. I don’t perceive vanilla as this scent is very unsweet. Minimal in the base perhaps, but it’s kept in check. Nevertheless, the whole thing is very rounded and also sensual with this soft woody base. Overall, a great all-rounder that unfolds best at temperatures between 10 and 20 degrees.
Performance is good as expected from fragrances of this type. The scent impresses with a nice sillage and a longevity of 8-10 hours. Thus, it’s great for everyday use but also for the evening in a more elegant outfit. As mentioned, it’s a great all-rounder.

Overall, once again a great Ugolini release. This brand almost always impresses me with great quality and wonderful DNAs.

review_title: More conservative than the Rossos, yet a solid benchmark
review_content:
Oh yes, the citrusy opening is immediately ignited in the first minutes by an underlying pepperiness. Not pure citrus summer vibes, but interpreted in a masculine spicy way; the combination of pink and black pepper works well, the earthiness of one, the invigorating fruity-fresh spiciness of the other.

The transition to the heart is smooth, remnants of the citrus peels linger nicely for a bit longer, 30-60 minutes in and they can still be perceived behind the new green freshness. In comparison to the two Rossos, however, this one has a distinctly more conservative progression so far. Sure, there's pepper, but not so spicy that it becomes very niche, and otherwise we find ourselves in familiar territory, lacking the exciting smoky note of 4 Rosso or the special peach integration in a rose men’s fragrance of 17 Rosso.

90-120 minutes in, the base plays more, the combination of woods with grasses and styrax has this special note that always reminds me of roasted nuts and is pleasing, cedar adds a bit of freshness, vanilla rounds it off nicely. Here it becomes warmer, remnants of the pepper are present and play nicely with the woody notes.

I don’t know, to be honest, it was a bit of a disappointment after the 2 Rossos, which positively surprised me with their somewhat unusual, everyday composition. This one is definitely more conservative and "Ah yes, I know that one." Don't get me wrong, it's still a high-quality fragrance with very good longevity, medium sillage, etc.
But I would rather reach for something more special from the house; that might just be my hipsterism. ;)

Oxford, the name stands for one of the most well-known shoe models for men ever. Naturally, it fits perfectly with the brand Roberto Ugolini, who is a bespoke shoemaker in Florence. A great blend of citrus freshness and wood. Absolutely recommendable and, in my opinion, underrated. The target audience is definitely men. No unisex or anything like that. In terms of age, it's...

Oxford is the perfect entry into the world of niche fragrances.
Here, the wood and grapefruit create a wonderful scent for everyday wear.
Not too intrusive with moderate longevity.
The name says it all. I have never been to an Italian shoemaker, but I believe it smells exactly like that there.
However, for the price, the fragrance should have more impact.
So definitely try it out beforehand.

review_title: Best fragrance for a serious man?
review_content:
My experience with Oxford, I never really wore perfumes, due to my work as a self-employed direct seller I wanted a pleasantly scented fragrance that wouldn’t offend anyone, as I always deal with various people.
Very nice spicy woody not sweet, intense, 1-2 sprays are more than enough for me, very good longevity, for me still the best all-round fragrance, by now I already have a few different ones.

More suitable for spring, autumn, winter, or for occasions or evenings, also wearable in summer, but at 30 degrees I would rather wear something fresher, then I like to wear Pacific Rock Moss by Goldfield & Banks.

review_title: A Suitable Start into the Niche
review_content:
After my first purchase of Blue Suede Shoes by Roberto Ugolini, I wanted to learn a bit more about the brand's perfumes and came across Oxford and 17 Rosso.
First, I took a closer look at the Oxford:
Through my research, the Oxford was described to me as "an easy entry into the niche," and that is pretty much what it is. It is uncomplicated and easy to wear, but it stands out with its fruity, spicy, and also woody characteristics.
It starts off for me with a fresh grapefruit, which is quickly complemented by a peppery note. After a while, the scent begins to transform into a very masculine woodiness, which is still accompanied by pepper and a slowly fading citrus note.
By now, the Oxford has practically become my signature casual scent. Unfortunately, it would be too strong for work.
All in all, in my opinion, it is the perfection of a "standard" men's fragrance and definitely worth acquiring.
Blind buy definitely possible :)

Oxford, the shoe that always works, so they say. But can the scent keep up? That was my first association upon receiving this fragrance. At first glance, one can say the bottle fits the name, classic and unobtrusive. The craftsmanship, as is typical for Ugolini, is top-notch. Now to the scent, I was initially skeptical because the fragrance notes could...

Oxford is often associated with the blind buy beginner niche fragrance. To begin with: it is indeed that!
The scent features a grapefruit note, accompanied by a spicy pepper. With its stylish and universal charm, it is perfect as an addition to a classy suit, avoiding any awkwardness with colleagues. However, the longevity is not the best for a niche fragrance in the moderate price range! Personally, I have to reapply throughout the day.

My opinion on Oxford. First of all, the scent is named after the men's shoe Oxford and not the university. The name actually says everything about the fragrance. It fits perfectly with brown dress shoes. The scent is very mature and very serious for me. In the top note, I mainly smell fresh notes. After about 20 minutes, the pepper kicks in. The pepper makes the fragrance very spicy in a positive way. An hour later, the sandalwood and patchouli come to the forefront. The sandalwood makes the scent very rounded, and the patchouli adds a playful touch for me. As for the performance, I can only say that it is good, but not outstanding. It is definitely not a BEAST mode fragrance. Perhaps that's why it is so perfect for the office and everyday wear. I perceive the scent for about 6 hours.
Conclusion: I think the scent is great, but for me, it is suited for men aged 25 and up. A blind buy is recommended if you are looking for an office/leisure fragrance and enjoy pepper and leather.

Designed as an office fragrance, Roberto Ugolini's "Oxford" shines on all levels.

Its very noble spicy woodiness is interrupted by refreshing citrus-green notes.

However, I noticed after wearing it repeatedly that the scent is not only a top pick in work situations but also resonates excellently with women (a good friend of mine would now say: "You know women?").

Well, anyway, it is also a real "compliment-getter" in everyday life, both from women and men... and that's why I would like to categorize this fragrance as an ALL-PURPOSE WEAPON.

It is definitely worth ordering at least a sample!

The Oxford by Herbert Stricker is, in my opinion, an everyday scent for the office. A beautiful fragrance for people who wear suits. Woody notes paired with a hint of citrus and pepper. The scent is not intrusive. You simply smell very pleasant and definitely receive a lot of compliments. The longevity is also great. (6-8 hours) The sillage is not overpowering, but you always...

review_title: Fresh Grapefruit with Too Dominant Pepper
review_content: I got the Oxford in a sample set and it was time to test it. At first, the citrus notes of grapefruit can be smelled along with the intense pepper. However, over time, the grapefruit gradually fades into the background. The pepper, on the other hand, remains very present, extending into the base, and is personally too intense for me. Later, the woody, resinous, and creamy...

I bought my first niche fragrance with Oxford and was not disappointed. The Oxford is a very beautiful woody scent that is not too overpowering yet still strong. For me, it fits perfectly in the autumn and winter and will become a lovely companion during these seasons. In short: A pleasant, rather masculine scent that is very likable and does not offend.

This was my first blind buy as I heard a lot about the fragrance and saw some videos about it, I immediately knew what I was dealing with. And I was not promised too much. Since I really like bold masculine scents, this is a great fragrance for me. It reminds me of the time in old England when the Peaky Blinders roamed the streets in their stylish suits. One could also compare it to a more modern businessman from Birmingham, carrying his dark brown leather messenger bag with the most important documents. A wonderful, very beautiful, peppery yet noble and elegant scent. You stand out slightly from the crowd. I find it like a suit that you just had made at your trusted tailor - nothing is missing, every detail has been carefully planned. There’s no missing button, no waistcoat. All in all, a very successful fragrance for the autumn/winter season that wears like a tailored suit.

This is how I envision a classic men's fragrance. The scent starts with mild citrus fruits and gentle pepper. From there, the other fragrance notes gradually join in and embrace the rose geranium leaf. The individual base notes each say hello, but they don't push themselves too much into the foreground. The fragrance becomes smoother and rounder. The notes don’t want to...

A fragrance without a season, you can really wear it anytime. I find it has a high recognition value, and I often get approached about it. Some find it very invigorating, while others consider it too old-fashioned.
I have to say I was never a fan of orange/grapefruit before, but that has clearly changed here. The peppery note is, in my opinion, spectacular.
The sillage is not too strong; most people comment on the scent when you walk past them in motion. The price might be a bit too high.
So overall, it's a confident fragrance for any occasion, and you stand out. The citrus note is refreshing and invigorating. I like to give myself a spritz at home, just to have it active in my nose again :)

review_title: Noble Fresh Fragrance with a Spicy Accord. Fun to Wear
review_content:
The Oxford is for me a truly high-quality fragrance in the fresher category.

It has a wonderful
grapefruit-orange combination in the top notes. This mix lasts really well and is supported by spicy accords that fit perfectly.

As a fundamental base, the Oxford has something woody paired with patchouli and vetiver.
Green vibes resonate.
As sweet counterparts, vanilla and styrax come into play.
The resinous element combined with the vanilla nicely rounds off the base and, together with the other notes of the fragrance pyramid, creates a fantastic overall work of art.

The Oxford feels totally serious, elegant, and high-quality.
For a fragrance of its kind, it is particularly special.

Longevity and sillage are really good for a fragrance that tends to be fresher. Commendable!

Definitely worth testing this gem.

review_title: Fresh/Woody perfect for the office but not for the young
review_content: This scent reminds me of a freshly cut wooden board drenched in lemon, in a very good way. Oxford fits perfectly into everyday life and can actually please just about anyone. The Ugolini fragrances are known to be made for the slightly older man, and I would count this one among them. Fortunately, I only ordered a sample. Although I think the scent is great, it feels a bit...

Oxford by Roberto Ugolini is THE scent for the office and especially for client meetings. It exudes seriousness and trust for me. It is extremely strong right after application, but then it fades and is still pleasant to smell after 3-4 hours. Optimal for men who enjoy a woody, smoky, and leathery scent.
Personally, it's not really a casual fragrance but rather effective only in a business environment. However, it is by far the best for that purpose.

When I first smelled this fragrance, I was immediately convinced. On the skin, it is even better than just in the nose. For men with class, whether in the office or for going out. It can be worn well in everyday life, neither too strong and intrusive nor too weak and characterless. Recommendable, moderate, and masculine for those who like it smoky/woody/leathery.

The Oxford by Roberto Ugolini was an absolute blind buy and I do not regret it. The grapefruit, orange, and pepper harmonize perfectly.
For me, it is an absolute everyday scent, suitable for the office and also for going out…
The longevity should definitely be better.
On my skin, it is perceptible for at most 4 hours.

This was startlingly cloying and sticky, sickeningly sweet! I can't believe someone would take such a unique brand name and innovative bottle design and stick this purple high fructose corn syrup inside. I rarely say such things, in fact I try not to be boastful, in general...but I think I as an amateur fragrance maker, I could have done a better job with this one. Admittedly, I didn't get too far into this one, before my gag reflex indicated it wasn't for me. I got a blast of Ylang ylang and I sensed that bold rosewood note followed by the undeniable tuberose-jasmine complex and a bit of Osmanthus. Then all of a sudden...way too much sugary sticky Myrrhe, sticky heavy amber and candy vanilla. I never made it to the base notes, so I can not comment on the full dry down or the longevity. But I would put this in the corner with Cacheral's "LouLou", Susanne Lang's "Midnight Orchid", Bill Blass' diabetes inducing "Nude" and a number of other over the top toothache inducing fragrances. This is a 3/10 as far as expectations versus reality for me. Sillage 6/10 and abstain from the vote on longevity since I had to remove it long before it was ready to let go of me. Pesky fruit flies all around...ugh!

Flight of Fancy isn't as strong as I thought it would be, and that's a good thing.

When I read the notes I was preparing myself for an intense blast of lemon, litchi and yuzu, however when I actually tried this fragrance, the opening was light and sweet, not at all sour or sharp.

In fact Flight of Fancy is rather mild. It's peaceful and delicate, a great composition in my opinion. The fruity and floral notes come together nicely. I also detect a subtle hint of musk closer to the drydown which really softens the scent.

Flight of Fancy is wonderfully inoffensive. I wish that more people, especially young girls wore this. No matter how much of this you apply, I doubt that it would ever become too overwhelming.

This may not be the most unique fragrance you'll ever come across, but it certainly is appealing. It's pretty and feminine and that's all that matters to me. I'll admit that I was shocked to like this seeing that I've disliked most of Anna Sui's other scents.

This scent Flight of Fancy , is a plain , most likely inoffensive neutral scent. It strongly reminds me of United Colors of Benetton Essence of Woman . That is to say it smells like defanged ,watered down , light stonewashed patchouli, with some soft fruit and clean floral. Bottle is gorgeous! I'll be getting one for myself and probably one for my young niece ,as she'll probably spray herself silly with it.

I don't even know how to begin describing this miracle water. A few years ago, I stumbled upon it while searching for a fragrance that I could wear - not the other way around.

What can I say, it was love at first sight: the packaging and bottle come across as kitschy, a bit silly, almost sensational. Luckily, I didn't let that deter me back then!

When I apply it, it starts with a glassy-golden and citrus explosion that wakes me up, gives me a real freshness kick, almost coaxing me out of my shell in a tropical way, buzzing around me, only to reveal a noble and crystal-clear rose for several hours, which enters into a wonderful symbiosis with my skin, carrying me fresh and gently through the day, wrapping me closely and only perceptible to me and those who are allowed to come near. Every day I am anew enchanted by it; clear and yet warm, it slowly connects with spicy-warm woods that ultimately accompany me late into the evening, calming me and providing a cozy, warm feeling of home.

I have repurchased this fragrance countless times and was almost desperate when it became increasingly difficult to find and I suddenly could only get it through auctions. Now I have managed to snag three bottles as a reserve and am overjoyed to be able to wear it daily.

So far, I haven't found any comparable fragrance that connects so naturally with my own body scent, embraces me without clinging, accompanies me without annoying me, follows me without stalking me.

Flight of Fancy was an impulse buy when I was feeling frustrated, and now I don't know what to think of it or myself.

Actually, this scent doesn't fit my usual preferences at all, being fruity and floral as it is.
When I bought it, I found it more floral, and indeed very beautiful and sweet.

Now, during the new test, it starts off quite fruity and citrusy. However, you can also smell the lychee, which I like. This makes the scent immediately sweet, and the citrus notes do not overpower.
Not long after, the floral tones finally emerge, and I start to like the scent more.
I also think I can smell a powdery peach nuance.

The scent becomes quite sweet, but a fine woodiness and the amber prevent the sweetness from becoming unpleasant and add a note that sets the fragrance apart from the usual fruity-floral monotony.

Flight of Fancy is not a highlight, but it's also not a bad scent. It feels spring-like and is suitable for all ages.

The bottle is very beautiful, with a cap that depicts an engraved peacock.

When I discovered Flight of Fancy, I was so taken with it that I immediately bought two large bottles.
I find the bottle enchanting, and the fragrance is just as impressive.

The scent envelops me as lightly and delicately as the swallows that perform their acrobatics outside my window in early summer.
I never tire of watching them.
Moreover, the little birds bring summer with them.
So does the fragrance.

Lemon, lychee, and yuzu are so beautifully sunny, brightening the mood.
Freesia and rose let petals cascade down and draw one out into the greenery.
The cedarwood provides the subtle spice of awakening trees.

A fragrance that reflects a sunlit garden, over which cheerful swallows glide.

Despite my hoarding purchase, both bottles will soon be empty - and I will stock up again.

What I like most about this perfume is certainly the bottle, which looks so beautifully decorative and caught my attention.
Normally, I don't like it when a fragrance is too fruity. Here, I enjoy it; paired with the floral notes that gradually come to the forefront, it's not too much. The lemon doesn't smell like dish soap, as can sometimes be the case in fragrances - great, because that's how I love it.
I also think I can smell a hint of peach and something exotic that makes the scent different from other floral-fruity compositions. It must be the lychee and yuzu, although I'm not familiar with yuzu.
I quickly pick up on the rose, which I really like. This adds a certain elegance to the whole scent, in my opinion. But all in all, it's a youthful, modern, and fresh fragrance, great for everyday wear.

Addendum: The longevity leaves much to be desired, so I have to reapply during the day quite often. What a shame.

Second addendum on longevity: it lasts really long on clothing and in hair for such a fresh scent, especially considering it's an EdT.
I perceive it well and feel very comfortable with it when it's warm.

Even though it is citrusy, I really like the scent, with a slight sweetness in the background and barely detectable cedarwood, it almost reminds me of a lemon cake with icing and a hint of spice.
Lychee is sweet-fruity in the background, as well as a very authentic smelling rose like in "A Forbidden Affair." And there is hardly more to say, it smells very elegant and joins the other fragrances from Anna Sui that I have tested, all of which I find surprisingly positive.

I would like to write something about this scent now, but for me it's like spraying water. I can't smell it on myself at all.
Everyone around me perceives it, just not me. A real phenomenon, what is it trying to tell me?

review_title: Karma will take care of it
review_content: I don't find it bad at all... Not quite ripe pear, vanilla, tiare... Monoi and frangipani, I personally can't distinguish them anyway... I also perceive a bit of mandarin here. For me, this is not a sunscreen scent, more of a subtle summer companion. It slightly reminds me of Beach Walk (without that weird synthetic note), and I also think there’s a slight resemblance to Lyra * Alain Delon, of course just a fraction mixed with Zara's Blanche Ensoleille. I personally find the H/S of all the Tesoris I've tested so far to be the worst... but it doesn't bother me. I've had Trussardis, Diors, and LV's, which vanished in no time.

As always, I can't resist the fragrance shelves and with a glance, I skimmed over the new arrivals. I found the shower gels from the company to be decent so far, but I struggled with the scents. This was also the case with the new fragrance Karma.

As a teenager in the 70s, the orange color with the oriental pattern immediately caught my eye. Flower Power, flared pants, miniskirts, platform shoes, Abba, and George Baker Selection flashed through my mind in seconds. This fragrance had to be tested. I expected something with patchouli, the trendy scent of the time, but that was a swing and a miss.

The opening was extremely sharp and artificial, and I felt like I was back in those days. Memories of a Saturday in my neighborhood came flooding back. Uncle Jupp set up the bright red rubber boat and the orange steep-wall tent for the nudist vacation in St. Peter-Ording. His wife, Siggi, arrived with her hair all done up and a huge cloud of hairspray behind her, like concrete. Kids Daggi and Rolli had baked waffles but burned them. You could do that as a teenager. Then Grandma Änne showed up. Freshly permed curls tinted purple and smelling of hairspray and hair salon. Son-in-law Kurt rolled up with the bakery on wheels, and the smell of bread mixed in. Everyone examined Uncle Jupp's setup. Then his kids checked the air mattress and the swim rings. Now there was also the smell of plastic toys. Smoking was fashionable back then and not a half crime, and cigarette smoke wafted everywhere.

All this scent mixture is the fragrance Karma. The opening is artificial, then a full blast of flowers where frangipani, tiaré, and ylang-ylang fought over who would dominate the scent. Accordingly, there is a disharmony. Later, the remaining notes also fought, and again, there was no winner. To me, it was a stench. Sorry, but that's how I perceived the fragrance.

Longevity is quite long, and unfortunately, for sensitive people, it's a headache candidate. The bottle visually appealed to me, but unfortunately, the content did not. Luckily, I only tested it.

Tsar in Etruscan means ten.
And this is precisely the tenth fragrance of this brand.
10 is obtained from the total of the first four numbers, considered the number of perfection and at the same time of cancellation, it was thought to contain all the fundamental elements of the universe.
This creation, which may seem like yet another repetition of the rose/Oud/saffron combination, appears to my nose (which does not always appreciate these notes) to be really pleasant and well balanced, very wearable without being too opulent: no element prevails, the bergamot gives it freshness and the tonka bean creates a very sensual frame.
And yes, it is one of the few that I like in the genre and I would really like to wear it.
Sexy in its essentiality, truly beautiful.
I see it as ideal for the cooler seasons, or perhaps on summer evenings.
Excellent performance, lasts all day.
“With the Wind” drawn by Hughes.

review_title: It does smell like newly opened Macbook box
review_content:
The other review mentioning that it smells like a newly opened Macbook... is almost spot on. It does smell like when you open a new Macbook/iPad package. That airy, slightly cold metal smell.
However! I think the cloves note here is more prominent. So I guess it smells like if you're unboxing a new Macbook with a bowl of dried cloves next to you.

I actually find the scent to be so comforting and excellent. To be fair though, I do love the smell of cloves and new Macbook.

About its performance: on my skin & clothes, it has strong sillage. On my skin it lasts about 8+ hours before it becomes almost unnoticeable. On my clothes though... that's another story. I once gave 2 sprays on the blanket I use on my sofa, and my whole living room then smelled like this perfume for a whole week. It is beastly!

review_title: Not my styl.e. And yet, I wear it.
review_content:
I don’t usually like synthetic perfumes — the Molecule-type ones. Mostly because I don’t find them evocative, narrative, or descriptive. Plus, depending on the molecule, I sometimes can’t even smell them at all. So, 27 87 as a house — with Daniela Andrier behind several of their creations — has everything to put me off. They fully embrace their synthetic identity. Hashtag is no different. Some say it smells like opening a brand-new MacBook. They’re not wrong. There’s something plasticky, fresh — and then a curious incense note, light enough to be worn even in the heat. Musk, maybe.

It all evokes walking into a tech store run by someone cool, who added a faintly zen, chill touch to the decor. A very original perfume — and yet, super wearable and laid-back.

Not my style. And yet, I wear it.

Insta: switzer_scent

Either it was my husband's persistence, my mood when I first tested the fragrance, or whatever else it was that made me not like the scent at first, but now I really like it and it is now in my collection.

#Hashtag (what a silly name) is a clean, very bright, and slightly metallic-sounding fragrance without much of a scent development.

The defining notes are, besides a soapy-synthetic aldehyde, a glaringly bright incense. Iris subtly powders the scent a bit, without the note really coming to the forefront. The (cedar) wood is somehow present, without being distinctly noticeable. It rather adds a certain dryness to the fragrance.

That the scent supposedly smells like a freshly unpacked notebook cannot be claimed. To me, it smells more like a mix of laundry day and church space.

In my now-deleted statement, I wrote that the idea is not exactly new, and I still stand by that impression. But in the end, that is irrelevant when I like the concept (even if only after the third test) and feel comfortable with the fragrance.
And after all, opinions are sometimes meant to be changed, aren't they?

review_title: #Church scent would probably be more fitting
review_content:
In the description of the perfume, I imagined something soapy, fresh with a light incense note like Aqua di Gio Profumo.

Unfortunately, I was very disappointed, especially since it was a blind buy.

The first time I caught a whiff, I immediately thought of the comment that it is supposed to smell like a newly unpacked MacBook.

At first, I could really only smell something like something newly packaged.

After testing it a few times, I eventually smelled a bit more.
It smelled to me like being in a church with a slight freshness.

I only received one positive compliment that it smells like fresh laundry. Otherwise, most people thought I smelled like a church /:

Even though the scent is not my favorite, it has found a place for me.
I wear it on Sundays when I go to church :D

review_title: Frankincense for Hot Weather - Thank God ...
review_content:
... my wife now also has to tolerate frankincense on me in the summer!

With "#Hashtag | 27 87 Perfumes," we have a molecular fragrance that imitates the theme of "freshness" or possibly "fresh laundry" or "fresh linen," all enhanced with a note of frankincense. The frankincense is well noticeable, yet subordinate like a breeze of freshness. I find the composition really successful and finely balanced.

What I particularly appreciate about the scent is truly the idea...
Fragrance lovers and fans of more interesting notes and compositions will particularly enjoy this, in my opinion. Because with Hashtag, you don't get a classic, ordinary freshie, but a fresh linen DNA that provides an interesting twist through the frankincense, thus opening the door for frankincense into the hotter days!

Great idea, great scent, looks cool too...

I’m glad I have it!

Extremely beautiful, clean, and subtle unisex scent. I love the comparison to opening the package of a new MacBook as the scent really strongly resembles that smell. I can understand why some people do not like this pure, cold synthetic fragrance, but it speaks to me extremely. To me, #hashtag smells like cold air, new technology, and familiar nostalgia. A cool consequence of...

I took a great distance from this lens. I think it is a unisex fragrance that curls up to a female audience. The smell changes like a chameleon. but the dominant note is a delicate patchouli sweetened with pralines. I have a batch from 2017. the fragrance is not very designer, but it stays on for a long time. You can smell it on the clothes the next day.

The location of this charming rarity could not contrast more with its character. In the desert of Albuquerque, under the absurdly blue sky of New Mexico, stands a small white trailer among flea market stalls, street food vendors, and bargain tables.
Inside, there is not only a curious, versatile, and high-quality collection of fragrances - the storage space resembles Mary Poppins' handbag - but also two delightful young gentlemen who devote themselves "only" part-time to their passion for conscious, pleasurable, and curious smelling. I am warmly welcomed right away, subtly advised with knowing smiles, and the suggestions are all an eye-opener, almost all hits. Among a whole range of private Tom Ford fragrances, all of which can be filled in 10ml spray bottles, I am particularly taken by the French scent "Delice Infini" from La Bouquetière. I am warned. Not of getting lost in the infinity of indulgence, but of the glittery, shimmering layer that the delicacy brings. It is advised against applying it to textiles, but the velvety shimmer does not cause any discomfort to the skin; on the contrary, it guarantees a longer presence of the bouquet.
