So here I am, traveling to the new world, lingering between the old hunting grounds of the Navajos and the new ones of American gun enthusiasts, crumpled by the nonexistent humidity, uplifted by the vastness of the sky and the desert, and then suddenly transported into a Parisian salon, equipped with pompous canapés and simple lily arrangements. The ceilings are high, as are the arched windows, the air is cool, as are the glances of the young French women who sip their Crémant, play Rummy, and scrutinize and dissect the company of Mademoiselle Z. They float upright in their cloud of infantile arrogance, which is reflected in their scent; their distance has something piercing about it, yet it stings so sweetly, a little sour, like the pearls in cold sparkling wine. The longer we linger in the dignified yet lurking atmosphere of the salon, the more sluggish our spirits become. We sink into the too-soft backrest of the canapé, the fragrant aura of the room grows warmer, enveloping us in a hint of youthful patchouli, white flowers, and noble sweat. Outside, it is 20 degrees warmer than in the venerable vault, where lime sorbet and biscuit are now being served. Observing, being observed, in vigilant excitement, aware of one’s own nobility. In another world, people are sweating; one can sense it, one is part of the season, carrying the sticky summer in the heart, the coolness in the head and chest.

Back in Albuquerque, I spend the rest of the day with Delice Infini on my collarbone by the Rio Grande. Even at 35 degrees, this unique storyteller scent works, accentuating and contrasting the heat equally.

Take an old rotting wooden log. Set it to dry near a fireplace. Hollow it out, fill with dry dirt, whole vanilla beans, cinnamon bark and warm spices. Hide the log in the throne room of a sultan, let years of frankincense and sweet myrrh suffuse the wood. Heat the log over a fire and spoon some whipped cream on top.
Now step back and smell it as a complete scent: this is 24 Gold.

It wasn't love at first sniff, however. At first I worried that I'd received a dud batch or perhaps the oud note was not nearly what I expected. But I gave it time, first resigned to a bad blind buy, then cautiously optimistic, then enraptured! Gold is a good name for it, fitting in both hue and value; 24 Gold is one of few fragrances I have considered stocking up on just in case they decide to discontinue it, gold ingots stashed away from prying eyes.

It's not as much of a sillage monster on me as some others have described, I would actually prefer it to be stronger. It fares better sprayed on clothing but I enjoy it more when activated by body heat, so there's a trade-off. I do wish the bottle was a little transparent as due to the weight of it and the opaque metallic coating it is difficult to judge the level of perfume inside.

On a more personal note, I enjoy washing my hair with my coconut and Marrakesh oil conditioner and then liberally applying 24 Gold. Generally I avoid mixing perfumed products but they mesh together well. It encourages confidence and sensuality... I feel warm and mysterious, a desert priestess making libation.

Ok guys, here is my own story, just today 17:10PM with 24 Gold.

15:45 PM - I logged out from work and will head to post office to check on my perfume orders. My male co-worker that is logging out by 16:00pm ask me if I want a lift going home. I said sure then we can meet some place outside office after I checked my p.o. box. Deal! He said.

15:50 PM - I arrived at Post Office, heading to my box then went to the counter to claim. Postman gave me the box, I read the sender, expecting to get the Agent Provocateur or Le Dandy edt &/or edp.
But the seller was from Amazon which means, this is 24 Gold.

I opened the package, and saw the gold and black classy 24 Gold and checked the authenticity, serial no. etc. It all match, an assurance of authentic purchase. Now my last test would be, to spray it. Gold cap was great, easy and tight at the same time. I tried to spray once, no perfume came out, another, still nothing. Then I am solved that this is the real deal.

15:57 - 1 spray to back hand. Oh sweet first smell, reminded me of Paco Rabanne Ultra Red and 1 Million. Very vanilla, creamy top, a little powdery but very pleasant, could be guaiac wood but definitely no oud, yet. Powerful projection.

Three minutes after oud is slowly manifesting, subtle and very pleasing equally combining with jasmine which astonished my nose, making me convinced that this is wonderful indeed. After 10 minutes, its sweetness lessen and oud/floral combo much detected now. Such a beautiful scent that is sensual, well blended, transforming and very oriental but not cloying.

16:10 - The projection outside the post office is outstanding. The cold winds enhanced the fragrance. I was walking to meet my co-worker at the pharmacy, to ride with him and with just a spray on my back hand, the scent is a massive cloak in a winter afternoon.
Just amazing to experience it.

16:15 - I hopped in to his car and whoa, he smelled it already and told me what scent was that? It is strong but it smells very good. So I told him the brand and he wants to see the bottle and he smelled the sprayer and said, it is different from how it smells on me, different but very good aroma. He asked me where I bought it coz it is the first time he heard about this perfume.

So that was it, my actual experience with 24 Gold that ended with an immediate compliment.

My two cents: I felt the presence of oud, floral, balmy, vanilla, woods, some spices and powdery effect. But my over all take is that this a beautiful perfume that will surely earn compliment especially to women. It is really powerful but never cloying. It has the qualities of a well refined, unique, sensual and classy perfume that has some slight resemblance here and there with other known perfumes (Ultrared, 1Million, Tobacco Vanille, Armani Code, Fantasy) but able to hold the oud that pops in and out. This is a hell of a thrill ride that is worth its price. I can say it will have a following even for those who are into niche perfumes. This is a blind buy for me but a successful one, With a luxurious fragrance & a high class bottle & box, my precious...

24 Gold by ScentStory is one of those fragrances that proves that in this industry, as far as the consumer is concerned... all that matters is the juice inside! In other words "never judge a book by it's cover", and that really sums it all for this one! People thought that "how could a fragrance inspired by a TV show be any good?". Wow! How everyone was pleasantly surprised! Again, this really shows how much we value "brands" and "big names"... I mean if this was put in an exclusive flacon and released by a huge French fashion house (or by someone like Tom Ford) then we would be all over it! But instead it comes from a small company from the middle east and inspired by a TV show! Who would've thought it? Again it just shows you how quick all of us are to judge a book by it's cover!

So how does it smell? Well it is primarily an amber based fragrance (and a sweet one at that)! You have a combination between an amber softened by vanilla and musk (and also by the soft & creamy "woody" notes here like sandalwood, guaiac wood and oud - the last one in small quantities). I do actually detect the oud, but it's faint, and it doesn't overpower the fragrance in any way as the main notes of amber and vanilla dominate the scent.

Bottom line: This is a perfect scent for so many different occasions! I see it mainly as a cold weather scent, but if you spray very light it could be used for summer nights. It is (well) worth the money, which is very cheap for this level of quality in a fragrance... and it even puts some well established so-called "designers" to shame, by offering a borderline niche scent at half the price of a designer perfume! I would recommend this to people who like sweet amber or vanilla perfumes, with a woody background. It can be used casually, but I think this works best when you are out to "impress" in a formal setting (like a restaurant or high class bar), or an expensive banquet or something. If you can't test, and you like what I have just described, then don't be afraid to buy it. It is a sweet, woody, almost musky smell. Very warm and sensual. Especially good for winter and colder seasons. If you can't try it, buy it!

Events occur in real time...

The opening is sickly sweet and I assume this is due to the jasmine note which I guess I'm now not a fan of. I get gaiac with aoud faintly lurking in the background but never taking center stage.
Some users have detected a raspberry note, but this wasn't the case for me.
It takes about 20 minutes for the cloying to phase out. Not a fan at all in the opening, but hang in there & you will be rewarded in the dry down just as the case with the original A*Men.

After 20 minutes the fragrance smooths. It's a sweet woody tone, the aoud must be giving off a faint pulse, as I don't find it earthy or dry at all.

The dry down.. Beautiful..

Sure enough, like clock work I struck gold at the 90 minute mark..

It develops into a soft creamy gourmand scent. A solid 3-4 hours I'm left with a creamy vanilla custard scent, some cinnamon with a woody undertone.

It's sweet, but not a synthetic sugary scent 'Rochas Man' has which tends to be linear.
24 Gold definitely isn't linear, it's more refined & presents a luxurious vibe that is inviting but not dominating like '1 Million' is.

The projection up until this point has been very good.
5+hours in, it's approaching the skin scent stage. A gorgeous edible cinnamon scent.

This phase lasted for half a day (12 hours) no joke. I Woke up the following day, and I could still smell the trace on my hand, smelt like luxurious bar of soap.

Ideal scent

Warm, creamy, comforting & inviting in a subtle way.

If you enjoy 'Rochas Man', this is hands down the better choice. It's classier & smells more expensive.

Although '1 Million' has its own place in the night life environment, this is more ideal for a relaxed environment or occasions. Restaurant/movies/home/bedroom..

A lovely UNISEX fragrance which has an affordable price tag, smooth & creamy dry down which could be mistaken for a niche scent.

Verdict 8/10

I can easily smell the raspberry and the chocolate (and I happen to be a fan of raspberry), but it isn’t as nice as it sounds. I cannot understand all the good reviews. 24 Gold is too musky, and too harsh! Almost makes my eyes want to water. But while I appreciate the fact that it certainly isn’t feminine, I am sure there are better raspberry fragrances out there. I would rather wear something from the Dollar Store than to ever wear 24 Gold again.

I respect that this is very unique to me and most people you meet won't have smelled anything like this. It is the longest lasting fragrance I've ever had with monster projection and longevity. But it just doesn't smell good, it's got a weird smell to it that I can't put my finger on. Definitely not mass appealing everyone I asked said they dislike it (12 people). Some said it...

review_title: No bad bot not good like mid
review_content: Fear and Loathing in Perfumes Scents are subjective, but it's intriguing how we can always find someone go full glue-sniffing unhinged, in their vitriolic exaggerations in describing a standard Oud scent: one unc in the reviews has literally compared this to a vag*na from the middle ages while writing a full episode of middle ages whattapad fanfic of said woman taking...

review_title: The perfect gift for ex-partners, GEZ collectors, and everyone else you deeply hate
review_content:
I should have known... This unbelievably cheap-looking bottle, both in terms of material, color, and print. This manufacturer's website. And then there's the fact that the scent boasts being licensed from the "official 24 television series." All of this screams "James Bond drugstore scent, but poorly made" and "Stay away!!!" A thousand red alarm lights hang from the ceiling, someone stands in front of me and shoves an oversized "STOP" sign in my face. "Don't do it niiiiiiiiight....." I hear someone echo behind me with an outstretched arm...

What do I do? I beam at the scent bottle at the end of the dark corridor, which stands like the artifact in Indiana Jones' "Raiders of the Lost Ark" on a lit pedestal. My eyes sparkle. It is supposed to smell like vanilla. And vanilla. Also vanilla! OMG, yes, I have to have it. After all, I love CH Men, and if the scent isn't sweet, who is? Excuse me, someone down there has already warned another CH Men lover about this scent? Oh well, tastes differ. I WILL love this scent because I love vanilla! And when you think about vanilla, you always have that beautiful natural Bourbon vanilla in mind or rather in your nose. A lovely, milky scoop of vanilla ice cream, bought from the best ice cream shop in the whole city, on a beautiful summer day. Ah, delightful! What am I still talking about, I have to take that bottle off the pedestal and spray it on myself. Excuse me? Oh yes, of course, the payment for the sample first. Here, 5 €, please, now let me finally sniff!!

...

...

OH MY SH
*!!!! What the hell is THAT??

Anyone who loves this scent (and can thus obviously take a sick leave for life) should please stop reading. Because now begins a review of the worst kind. Because this creation from hell deserves nothing else.

Actually, I’m not one for pessimism, I usually refrain from commenting on scents I don’t like. But THIS is not a scent (which is why I will henceforth refuse to call it a scent, out of respect for the feelings of the other 66,000 perfumes here - let’s call this scent RTL, as smell and broadcast program are equally bad). This stuff is vanilla pudding that was left out in the blazing sun in summer 2013 and has been sitting in the same spot ever since. By now, countless insects have crawled in and promptly perished. And while they rot in this spoiled pudding, someone from ScentStory comes along and bottles it up. Of course, opaque, so you can't see the goo inside. Quickly rummaged through the trash and found some golden plastic foil from last carnival. Wrapped it around, traced the "24" from a radio alarm clock from the €1 store, and off to the shelves. Oh dear, even perfumeries like Douglas have a reputation to lose and refuse to offer this thing. After a Douglas employee immediately fell into a coma while sniffing the sample and a police report was threatened, the man from ScentStory ran out of the store, pondering. How does he sell this garbage to men/women?

“HA!” *snaps fingers like Vicky* “There’s this YouTuber, Jonas, Jeremias, or whatever his name is. He said several times he would wear crap if women liked it! [Original statement, note from the editor.] I’ll give him this junk, tell him women would go crazy for it, take my grandma and my sister with me to fake a bit of “Ohhhh!” and “Ahhh!” (after they’ve smeared some neutralizing cream from pathology under their noses) and BOOM, he’ll promote it and I’ll get rich, ahahaha, RIIIIICHHH!!”

And indeed, RTL achieves an unbelievable 7.9 in the Parfumo rating. I can only explain it by assuming that the people who have rated this crap so far thought it was a school grading system from 1 to 6, and 6 wasn’t enough for them. It wouldn’t be enough for me either.

Why the hell are there no negative numbers available here?!

Projection and longevity, I can unfortunately confirm without a doubt. For me, a solid 10! I sprayed a mini-squirt on my right arm and immediately an EMT stormed into the office asking where the patient was. Despite washing multiple times, I can’t get RTL off my skin. I now fear that it will still be detectable at my wedding (and I don’t plan to get married in the next ten years). Haha, my wedding! As if I would ever find a woman with this stink bomb... Forever alone, thanks to 24 - that would at least be an honest slogan!

So, for heaven’s sake, please do not buy this scent! You can’t possibly hate yourself so much that you would want to put yourself through this and even pay money for it!

Speaking of hate, this RTL is perfect for misanthropes! Do you want to have your peace? Don’t want to be stupidly approached from the side, like being asked for directions? Put on a gas mask and wear RTL! The whole gym is full again, all machines occupied? Wear RTL and the training area belongs to you! You’re throwing a party and the guests just won’t leave? Wear RTL and go to sleep peacefully ten seconds later. This thing is a better "bouncer music" in a club than any slow waltz!

Maybe I’ve just approached this all wrong and considered RTL as a “scent,” while its purpose lies in a completely different field: self-defense! In times when everyone is getting pepper spray and the prices have skyrocketed, like helicopter pilots when they smell RTL on the ground, 24 Gold comes just in time! This thing is better than any CS gas you can buy. A spray of it on the attacker and he will scream and run away. The best part is, you don’t even have to hit him in the face. A spray on his clothes is enough. Or just on the advertising column 20 m away from him. No phone or wallet that he could steal will be worth it to him.

And for the sensitive souls who always avoid satire magazines like “Titanic,” please forgive me this dark sentence, but if several people wore RTL, Cologne wouldn’t have happened. An arm's length distance? Good joke, Ms. Reker! A tiny spray particle of RTL on skin or clothing and the Cathedral Square belongs to you alone!

Therefore, as a scent, it has failed miserably (down to the core of the Earth, shot out the other side, and disappeared somewhere in the vastness of space, where it will be found by aliens who will cause revenge for a new “Independence Day” on Earth), but as an expression of “I hate you all and want you to know it!” it is perfect.

PS: I offer this crap in the souk, but I wouldn’t advise anyone to buy it. Not even for the ex-partners mentioned in the title who cheated on you, then crashed your Porsche, and subsequently emptied your bank account. You can’t hate a person so much that you would gift them this scent.

Last night, 10:15 PM in the kitchen. I had just come home from the afternoon shift and my significant other greeted me with a raised eyebrow and a wrinkled nose, saying, "You don't usually wear that, do you? I don't know it at all, what kind of glue is that? Phew, it just smells like vanilla... no, I take that back, it STINKS only of vanilla!!! You have so many great scents...

I wouldn't have thought it possible to encounter this fragrance in the wild, given the apparent production shortages.
Unfortunately, the bottle tends towards a similar tackiness as "1 Million." The fact that I’m not presented with a gold bar makes the impression of the bottle only slightly better. I hope the contents are better than the exterior suggests...

The opening of "24 Gold" offers, among other things, warm, spicy, resinous sweetness. I smell oud, not necessarily the highest quality, a diffuse, Christmas-like spice note, as well as hints of guaiac wood and floral-fruity tones that I cannot identify, which, however, fade away within the first few minutes. Sounds quite nice at first.
Unfortunately, the main player looms over it all. Sticky-sweet vanilla from start to finish. At the beginning, this sweet interplay of synthetic vanilla, resinous, gnarly oud, and the subtle, balsamic-sweet guaiac wood is overwhelming; I can initially only sense the spices and woods of the heart note.
Fortunately, the vanilla gradually recedes and finds an interesting balance with the spices and woods. I distinctly smell anise and fine sandalwood, with clove, cardamom, and dry cedar lurking beneath. Perhaps also a pinch of cinnamon, but I'm not sure. Together, this creates a light black tea or more aptly chai note with woody accents. Unfortunately, the overly sweet synthetic vanilla is still too present for my nose to warm up to it.
Towards the end, the sweetness of the vanilla finally subsides, and "24 Gold" becomes for me an almost wearable, amber-warm, distinctly vanilla cuddle scent.

I almost feared such an outcome with the fragrance pyramid and classification, but at the same time, I’m glad to have tested this scent. I can very well imagine the fragrance on guys in their prime disco age (especially considering the enormous longevity and projection) and also on some women. However, I don’t want to smell like that.
Now I have a craving for homemade vanilla pudding. Off to the kitchen! :)

review_title: Golden Secret Tip, Not Just for Oud Fans
review_content:
I would have never bought this without the YouTube hype surrounding the 24 fragrances here... but it was absolutely worth it, and I can only join in the praise. So much fragrance for so little money, and then also from a series like celebrity scents - you don't expect that, and you are almost shocked and overwhelmed by the niche quality. A very noble, fine powdery oud scent and one of the biggest surprises of the year, definitely a recommendation to also test the remaining 24 fragrances. But that’s something you can hardly do anywhere, so interested parties will probably have to buy it blind. But with the prices, it's bearable, and Gold is a charming, party-appropriate oriental scent that doesn't overwhelm western noses.

It reminds me of Dior Homme Intense or even M7, quite precisely in the middle of the two. But still unique and very pleasing. Woody and powdery, luckily there are only jasmine nuances. Instead, there’s a lot of syrup, vanilla meets raspberry/strawberry. Dreamy, sweet, and bitter at the same time. The floral elements only form the bright frame for the bitter-dark painting. It even has the chocolate/cocoa elements of a DHI or some Montale. Jammy and perfect for rainy autumn days. For me, the sweetness even stays behind the oud and never overdoes it.

Bottle: chic, golden, handy in the 50ml variant. Still, it didn’t have to refer so blatantly to the (very good) series with 24. Among fragrance enthusiasts, that’s somewhat frowned upon. But the scent itself usually convinces even the biggest critics.
Sillage: strong, dark, mysterious, and a sweet vanilla-anise undertone make it suitable for going out. And almost exclusively so. It’s way too strong for the office, too powerful and sweet for leisure activities.
Longevity: 10-12 hours. Another strong point!

Anyone who tests it blind would think more of Amouage, Armani Privee, or Tom Ford - all the more surprising that it’s really a scent from the Fox series. A dream scent that walks the fine line between oud-dark and syrup-sweet. I hope it finds even more fans and is my budget tip for the coming winter!

review_title: And when you wake up, I'm no longer Manuel Neuer
review_content:
That's exactly how I imagined it when I had the sample of 24 Gold on my arm and later on my neck: The hope for a 100% gourmand vanilla scent! In the end, however, it was all just a dream.

"If you want, you can have everything!" says the nice lady next to me on the sofa. Damn it, how does she know what I want? I want cola when I order cola, not Cola Zero! Stuck label - Pah, what a cheater. She can wriggle around on the little bed as playfully as she likes!

I know gourmand scents - I have a whole shelf full of them! And indeed, 24 Gold belongs to this category. However, if you've experienced some of the higher-end fragrances during your perfume journey, then 24 Gold simply lags a bit behind. I find it synthetic and lacking depth and strength.

Or maybe it's the power of habit, because once you're hooked on cola, all other drinks taste strange. I don't know, decide for yourself!

Anyone who likes, admires, enjoys, and wears this scent should do so with pride. I wish you all the best with it. As for me, I don't celebrate with 24 Gold in the stadium, in the locker room, or with a nice girl in pajamas on the sofa. Why? Because it promised me more than it ultimately delivered.

Cheers!

Negative headlines are known to be the best headlines. This is also the case here. Thanks to some partly grandiose and stylishly formulated comments, I became aware of this fragrance. Due to this perfect negative advertising, my expectations were high. What must this olfactory beast be, what an overwhelming experience? Can I even smell it or will it burn my nose hairs away in an instant? Is "it" even allowed on the skin or do I risk severe burns?

I had to get a sample! I couldn't miss this, I was too curious and sensationalist. Sprayed on in anticipation of a vanilla smack, waited... nothing. Huh, where is it? Sprayed again... a slight whiff of plastic vanilla, then nothing. Did I get the wrong sample or did my olfactory cells die at the moment of first contact? Well, lately it often happens that I can hardly perceive a new fragrance on the first test, however, my friend did not run out of the living room gasping for air, did not complain, nor did he turn green after three sprays of 24 Gold on my forearm. Either my skin immediately devours the scent, absorbing all the predicted terrible things from my writers in that instant, or our noses were numbed by the overdose. There was nothing more than a slightly artificial vanilla on a wooden base.

On the second test the following day, 24 Gold reached me, still miles away from being impactful. An unspectacular sweet wood-spice-vanilla, Oud not perceivable on me. Nothing special and similar to scents I've smelled countless times before, some better, some less so. A bit of Kalemat, a bit of Raghba. As someone here has already written, Bouquet Ideal also comes to my mind, which, however, becomes significantly sweeter on me and annoyed me after a short time.

In summary, 24 Gold is average. Not breathtakingly strong, but also not weak. Not particularly loud, not particularly quiet/unobtrusive. Not particularly sticky, but also not unsweet (yet still too cloyingly sweet for me). I didn't fall into a coma, my friend didn't leave me or throw me out of the apartment, my dog didn't leave the room howling, and my skin had no burns. That's just how it is with negative advertising - the expectations for the negatively advertised object are infinitely high, the craving for sensation awakens, and 24 Gold could not satisfy that.

Conclusion: You can wear it. But you don't have to.

Thanks to dear Achilles, I finally got to try this hyped fragrance. However, since I didn't find any hyped fragrance really great apart from Aventus, I was initially skeptical. That skepticism was basically unfounded, as the scent is quite well done. 24Gold is neither a disappointment, junk, nor a revelation. The problem is simply that you already know a large part of it. To...

Reformulation of my comment after a year on Parfumo:

24 Gold is for me the absolute crowning achievement of this ScentStory series, the outlier - because the others are, in my opinion, hopelessly unable to keep up. 24 Gold is still rightly
one of THE fragrances that easily surpasses many of my over 800 or more newly tested perfumes. It is still a revelation! 24 Gold is a damn revelation! The absolute fragrance twin of Kalemat, the only downside compared to Kalemat is that it lingers on clothing for days and on skin all day, all night until morning. The 24 says goodbye after a few hours, so you can nicely reapply. There we have the quality difference - but otherwise - Must-Have.

24 Gold is a blend of warm woods, vanilla pudding, oriental pastries, and spices, a souk in the midst of a sandy landscape, a wonderful Arabian oasis that I would love to drink - that is sandalwood and generally such great wood, so fantastically soaked with vanilla, oud, and amber. The fragrance offers an oriental creaminess that is unparalleled. It evokes wonderful fabrics at the bazaar, fragrant hair pomades, garments perfumed with various spices and incense, the scent of the Orient at over 30 degrees, mixed with the smell of sand.

The scent progression is linear for me, the skilled blend of oud, vanilla, and amber is ever-present. Not dirty, not musty, just sweet, creamy oud. This would be a fragrance that comes into the closer selection if one had to ruthlessly determine those that should accompany one longer, 24 Gold will accompany me for a long time. It is an allrounder, perfect for autumn and winter, but casual enough for summer, apart from the fact that I am not so tempted to differentiate there. It certainly does not overwhelm me when it's warm.
The fact that it is now supposed to be discontinued is not entirely clear to me, and anyone who has the opportunity to buy this should not hesitate long.

Dear community

Here I am again, the slow (internal Swiss joke / note from the author) Bernese. But when it comes to buying perfume, I can be quite quick. 24...oh yes, I loved that series! It did get a bit stale after a few seasons with the same old formula, but that’s how it is with all long-running series. And the scent to go with it? Jack Bauer - full of energy, aggressive, selfless, intelligent. Action-packed! Something adventurous had to come out of this!! So what did the marketing folks and fragrance engineers come up with and launch???

I read reviews about it and watched some videos. Almost everyone is thrilled! And when I read through the pyramid, it looks like I should love the scent. Because: it’s sweet, a lot of vanilla...a lot of powder, a bit of wood. Yum, a winter scent for me? Could this replace my favorite cozy scent CH Men by Carolina Herrera? NO! Clearly!

I had to buy the scent online since it’s nowhere to be found (at least not in our small provincial capital). I assumed it would at least be mediocre, but...

The first spray on my wrist. A cloud hit me...really disgustingly artificial. What did it remind me of? Yes right, there used to be this artificially sweet vanilla pudding LIGHT. Omg, that was dreadful. And the scent now, what can I say to be polite? Artificially overly sweet Light-vanilla-something. But truly a yuck effect for my nose. You know what I mean, everyone has those scents that just smell disgusting to them. Unfortunately, 24 is one of those.

I still give it 40% because after a few hours it wasn’t quite as disgusting, but still definitely too sweet. Lol and I’m saying this, of all people, the one who could bathe in CH Men. Be that as it may. Unfortunately, this was a wrong purchase. At least it wasn’t expensive.

I really like vanilla ice cream, but this is just...artificial-powdery...nope, not at all. Especially not on a man over 25, but that’s just my opinion. It might be least noticeable if you’re baking cookies in winter and a lot of vanilla is floating around the room, then it might still work.

Wishing you a lovely autumn and see you at the next scent.

I don't want to spend too many words on this; others have already described the scent in detail.

To me, it only smells of overpowering synthetic vanilla, which makes you feel a bit nauseous. Oud can be detected a little in the background, but it doesn't stand out since the vanilla has already knocked it out in the first round.

The longevity was to be expected, very good; it would have been wise to tone it down a bit.

Not only does the design of the bottle share similarities with 1 Million, but also its abominable dirty sweetness.

At first, a fine rosy note can be perceived, which brings a very subtle smoky hint thanks to the guaiac wood. At the same time, a delicate, sweet, bright floral note is noticeable, which merges with the guaiac wood into a whole. I can very well imagine that the interplay with jasmine allows one to perceive a sweet raspberry, which completely disappears the closer I smell to...

First of all, I just have to say I'm completely blown away... What a magnificent fragrance !!

My first experience with a unisex fragrance was Meharees, which disappointed me quite a bit and also came off as far too feminine.

I was initially skeptical about 24 Gold and was pretty sure that it would disappoint me as well.

But I was so wrong that it couldn't have been any other way....

If I had to describe the scent briefly, I would say: A magical blend of "Opium Pour Homme," "Dior Homme Intense," and a hint of "Jubilation XXV Man."

Many might disagree with me here, but I suppose I shouldn't care.

It has that sweetness that comes from the berries in Opium Pour Homme, along with the delicious and soft vanilla. Then there's the seductive and elegant element of Dior Homme Intense, combined with the nobility and class of Jubilation XXV Man.

I can smell all of these more or less in this fragrance.
At first, the sweetness is really almost a bit too much, and the floral notes in the fragrance make it extremely soft. It would be a bit too feminine for me.

Then, after a while, when the vanilla takes over, the fragrance becomes a dream. Vanilla and amber enchant you, and there's a touch of cinnamon that gives the scent a subtle spiciness.

Jasmine and ylang-ylang skillfully play with the sweetness of the fragrance and meet relatively bright woods that lend a slightly masculine note to the scent.

This fragrance simply blows me away and could become my new favorite next to Dior Homme Intense.

The scent is the perfect blend of sweet, woody, and floral elements. Accompanied by a very dominant vanilla towards the end, a bit of cinnamon, and a slightly smoky amber with a hint of festive anise.

The fragrance fits perfectly with the Christmas season and thus into winter. On relatively cold autumn days, I can still imagine wearing it. But definitely nothing for spring or summer.

24 Gold is, after or maybe even alongside Dior Homme Intense, the most delicious oriental gourmand I have had the pleasure of getting to know.

The fragrance really lasts extremely long, and I can still smell it on myself after many hours. After 5-6 hours, it becomes closer to the skin, but even then, the sillage is still enough to let others partake in this masterpiece. Especially outside on cold days, your fellow humans will be delighted when a light breeze carries this scent to them. The fragrance creates an irresistible warm aura that one cannot escape. Warm, elegant, seductive, and even a bit sensual and erotic, it radiates all of that.

Longevity 9/10
Sillage 9/10
Scent 10/10
Price 100/10

As you can probably see from the points I have given here, the price scores extremely well.

I really can't explain how a fragrance of this class and level can have a price of under €30 for 100ml.
The fragrance is definitely unisex, and I would say it is equally wearable for both genders, but I would actually assign it a little more to men. Thus, it is easier for me to wear it with a good conscience !!

The fragrance was released in 2009 and is therefore a masterpiece of recent perfume history and will most likely one day attain the status of a classic.
For a long time, I searched for a winter fragrance worthy of residing alongside DHI and Midnight in Paris in my fragrance cabinet and settling there permanently.

Now I like it so much that it might even get the presidential suite.
In the end, I can only emphasize again: "an incredible fragrance"

Everyone should test it and take the opportunity to acquire such a masterpiece for an extremely low price.

For the title of my comment being speechless, I have really found a lot of words, but I couldn't possibly withhold what I think of this fragrance from you.

Deserved 100%, and now the cold winter days can finally come, I am ready !!

So I have to go from 100% to 90%.

It doesn't quite reach my favorites DHI and MIP.

The fragrance is great, but already quite feminine, and the extreme sweetness can become overwhelming after a while. I definitely can't wear it regularly.

review_title: Sugary Raspberry Syrup on an Oriental Spice Cart, Served with Wood Shavings
review_content:
Yes, ScentStory is niche. Niche does not always have to mean elegant or particularly high quality, as the past has shown. For example, Yves de Sistelle can also be considered niche: not widely available and hard to find everywhere.
So what should one expect from a company that designs fragrances in series? ScentStory has fragrances not only for 24 but also for Gossip Girl and The Mentalist in its lineup. I have already researched and submitted these carefully, so they should appear here soon. In principle, ScentStory is a company that produces star fragrances. And they have not always been able to convince with originality or quality in the past. (A pleasant exception here is Madonna's Truth or Dare, a wonderful scent!)

Skeptically, I get to work, many thanks to the generous donor without whom I probably would never have been able to test this fragrance.
I press the sprayer and at the same moment I wonder if that was the tester or if I accidentally activated the raspberry scent atom bomb. Everyone in the room has to wrinkle their noses, but at the same time, big eyes are also made. Not bad if we die! That would be a delicious and beautiful death.
A sugary raspberry syrup scent spreads, there is really a great power behind it. I cannot understand how the longevity and sillage are rated so poorly here. The raspberry smells like syrup, but not plasticky-synthetic, rather relatively authentic, "saturated" and round. A few seconds later, however, disappointment sets in: the raspberry is overwhelmed by an army of spices and whines softly in the background. But the disappointment does not last long, as this is only the case directly on the skin. A few handbreadths away, or rather the scent trail that you drag behind you, is again dominated by the raspberry. Shrill notes penetrate everything in the fragrance world. Fruity, sugary sweet but very well contrasted with some sharp spices, which in turn is pleasantly rounded off by a creaminess. While the scent on the skin is not at all my thing, I move in a cloud that can completely convince me. If this scent could be made visible, I would probably just about be recognizable in a pink mist. It’s that strong!

Quality and originality get full points. But is the scent suitable for everyday wear? No! Am I interested in that? Somehow less. I am young and a student, I can wear what, where, and when I want. Surely the scent is also not for the European, and yet - one must say - conservative masses. This scent plays in the innovative league of the Middle East, where it comes from, and perhaps also the USA. And for the typical vintage and classic fan of Parfumo, this is also nothing. Good, because this one is for me!

Oh, I somehow understand the people who call 24 Gold cheap swill. It is indeed a very cheeky scent that, in my opinion, aims to polarize intentionally. 24 Gold does not rely on being loved by everyone. The often mentioned synthetic vanilla has something truly special about it. And then it is cheekily mixed with an oud that seems to belong to the sweatier type of oud, making this scent really mega exciting.

The fragrance starts with its special vanillin blend that strongly resembles raspberry. This very sugary vanilla is mixed with delicious woody notes that are not immediately recognizable. But you perceive them from the beginning to the end.

An extremely strong sillage surrounds the wearer for at least 2 hours. Due to the strong caramel vanilla note, I would love to smell it on a woman. I would even argue that this is actually not a unisex fragrance but the perfect women's scent. How I would love to admire it on a beautiful woman and then realize that my brain is totally manipulated by this genius fragrance. The longevity is long and strong. You can perceive this scent on the wearer for about 8 hours without direct skin contact.

For me, 24 Gold is a throne sniffer because it truly overshadows some of my previous discoveries. I didn't expect much from such a cheap fragrance. Also, the fact that it is so hard to get is actually not a good sign. However, you immediately realize that you were mistaken. It has made it into my Top 5, even though I probably prefer it on women rather than on myself. But it is soooo incredibly pleasant. It is like food for the nose.

Maybe you know the feeling that every time you smell it, you are amazed at how wonderful a fragrance can be, and you keep marveling at how good a scent is. I experienced exactly that here. My Body Kouros remains my favorite, but 24 Gold is also a different, sweeter direction. But it manages to rank right behind Kilian's Back to Black for me. Thanks to Jens123 who gave me the tip in the forum. Really, a thousand thanks!

Well, sooner or later you inevitably come across 24Gold if you are interested in fragrances. When I was made aware of it through YouTube, I eventually ended up here at Parfumo to somehow find out how to get my hands on this scent. I’m glad I landed here.

Like my predecessor VD86, it was extremely exciting to unpack the bottle, especially because of all the raving here. But I didn’t let myself be swayed and approached this scent with skepticism so as not to think prejudicially, "Oh, it must be wonderfully delightful."
However, the first spray left me astonished; it is simply so beautifully different from everything else.

A noble vanilla sweet and creamy meets wood and is confused by amber and spices. On top of that, just the right drop of naughtiness and wickedness. I have no idea what it is, but you would almost want to lick it off yourself. Sorry for this little digression, but there seems to be something in it that is somehow really sexy.

In my opinion, the vanilla dominates, although this spicy note is also very strong. It’s as if you walk into a tea shop and there... oh, let’s forget about describing that; it’s certainly not possible without slipping into a naughty corner.

I have to agree, the scent is overwhelming but also very feminine. In my eyes, it is the perfect women's fragrance. It doesn’t smell cheap, even though it is. It stands out completely from what I know. Sometimes you smell a fragrance in a perfumery and try to recognize similarities, but here I forget any comparison because it just doesn’t work.

I must say that you can definitely buy this scent without knowing it. If you don’t like it, there will surely be enough buyers who will pay more than the import cost.

Conclusion: It’s a shame that this brilliant scent has such a silly name. I didn’t like the series. A name like "This is it" or "Must Have" would fit better. It’s a knockout how sexy vanilla is mixed here with spices, wood, and amber to create a perfect composition. Yes, and it somehow makes you addicted to smelling it. From me, 90% because it weakens in longevity after 5 hours. That probably means I won’t be able to avoid buying Kalimat. It’s supposed to be almost the same, just almost endlessly lasting.

review_title: Familiar DNA at a Reasonable Price
review_content:
This fragrance from the American brand Scentstory has been on the market for 15 years. For a while, this scent became quite rare and was sold by some shops at significantly higher prices. This usually indicates that production has been discontinued or temporarily halted. Now it is available again in some shops at fair prices. I have known this one for a while, and Jeremy also introduced this fragrance during his informative time. Price-wise, it's already a good catch. If you like sweet-oriental fragrances with gourmand-spicy notes, you are in the right place here.

You can find this fragrance at different price points. I paid a little over €20 for my 100ml, which is absolutely fair for this scent. This golden bottle is really pretty and can be quite enticing. The box is also quite attractive.
In terms of scent, it is one of many with this "Casamorati - Bouquet Ideale (Eau de Parfum) | XerJoff" DNA. Fragrances like Oud Save the King EAU DE PARFUM, "Kalemat | Arabian Oud / العربية للعود", or "Raghba / رغبة | Lattafa / لطافة" (which is in a similar price range) share this DNA. However, in the low-budget segment, this 24 Gold is already my favorite in this style. In my opinion, it doesn't quite reach the level of Casamorati, and the Atkinson is a bit more refined.
What I like about this fragrance is its sweet-oriental DNA with complex woods and warm gourmand notes. You don't really smell Oud prominently, yet this fragrance possesses a wonderful oriental spiciness. The dark Guaiac wood fits quite well with these oriental notes. The combination of sandalwood and cedarwood is also active in the background, providing a great foundation for this oriental sweetness. The vanilla sweetness is really pleasant and not too sticky-sweet. Ylang Ylang also contributes with a wonderful creamy note that rounds everything off nicely. The base is predominantly vanilla-amber with soft woods. However, the DNA from the opening remains consistent throughout, and the progression is rather linear. The fragrance is completely unisex and suitable for almost all occasions, except in summer and during sports activities.
The performance is quite good, lasting about 10 hours. The sillage also holds up well for several hours.

Overall, a great alternative if you like this DNA. I like it a bit better than Raghba as it feels a bit more refined.

Everywhere you turn, you read about this fragrance, everyone wants it, recommends it.
KrZa was kind enough to send me a sample, and everything I read was confirmed: beautiful vanilla, a bit of cedarwood, and amber. It smells incredibly good; you have to hold yourself back from applying too much. Last night, I received three compliments right away.
The scent goes on like oil; I would love to wash my clothes with it or mix a delicious vanilla shake, hahaha.
I’m thrilled, now I just hope that ScentStory releases something new or that I can find a bottle somewhere else...

When a fragrance is hyped up like this, I have to test it too. To be honest, I can't fully understand the hype.
Right after spraying, I notice a very nice, delicious vanilla. Great, I think, exactly what I love at the moment. The vanilla stays with me the whole time.
But after about a quarter of an hour, something else comes in. I don't know what I'm smelling. It can't be jasmine or anise, as I quite like those. Sandalwood or cedarwood don't smell that overpowering either. Is it the oud? No idea. In any case, it becomes quite unpleasant for me. A mix of bitter, sweet, artificial, which I just don't like. But I resist the urge to wash it off.
After an hour, I'm rewarded. It becomes really pleasant, amber and vanilla dominate the scent, and I start to really like it again. It lasts like this for almost 8 hours. If it weren't for that one unpleasant hour, I could completely understand the hype and would have given it 100%. But as it is, I have to make significant deductions for myself.
In the first 90 minutes, it has a quite strong sillage, but then it fades away.
For summer, in my opinion, it is too heavy and warm; it fits perfectly for winter. I also definitely don't see it as unisex; for me, this is a clear women's fragrance that I absolutely cannot imagine on men due to its quite strong sweetness.

When I became aware of "24 Gold | ScentStory," the hype around the fragrance was already over. Still, I had to have it to understand why there was once such a huge hype around the scent. Unfortunately, I was immediately disappointed because the perfume smells almost identical to a fragrance I once owned and did not like at all. This is "Raghba | Lattafa / لطافة," which,...

At first, I was quite ambivalent about whether I even wanted to go through the "bizarre" ordering process to test this perfume.

Ultimately, 24 Gold is a fragrance from the TV show "24". Accordingly, I had several prejudices regarding this perfume: how good or high-quality can a scent from a Fox TV show really smell? Wasted time, wasted money.

However, I was proven wrong. 24 Gold is, as the bottle suggests, a heavy, sweet gourmand scent and definitely something for the colder days. Whether the hype surrounding this fragrance, prevalent on many popular US fragrance forums, was justified still had to be seen.

I am not someone who shies away from sweet scents; I have several sweet fragrances in my collection - but initially, I struggled with 24 Gold. 24 Gold is really sweet, very sweet.

Once applied, you are immediately greeted by a berry, possibly raspberry. This fruity, berry note essentially dominates the top notes. After wearing it more often, you also perceive a slight woody note, but as mentioned, it is rather subtle, as the berry note strongly dominates. Oud is listed among the fragrance notes, but I don't smell it at all.

After the sweet, berry, and slightly woody phase, it gradually moves towards the drydown, where amber and vanilla take over the reins. Overall, 24 Gold is dominated by 2 notes: berry (raspberry?!) and amber.

It is a scent that many will not like at first glance - even those who enjoy sweet fragrances. I myself have gradually grown fond of the scent, and I like it more and more. The price-performance ratio is very good for this fragrance, because even if it may be too sweet, etc., the ingredients used seem high-quality to me and border on niche quality, or what one would imagine from niche fragrances. You can get the scent for $55/3.4oz, which is really very good for the quality of the fragrance.

Since the scent is really very "heavy", it is advisable to reach for the bottle only on cold days. Even for autumn, 24 Gold would be too much for me.

In conclusion, it can be said that 24 Gold definitely requires time. Many men in my circle of acquaintances find the scent far too feminine and far too sweet, and even though they are not very experienced in the world of fragrances, I can understand the "criticism". As mentioned, you can expect raspberry, amber, and vanilla, so you already know in advance where the journey is headed.

My only point of criticism is that 24 Gold is not very versatile. You really limit yourself, as I personally see no use for it except for cold days, and when it comes to occasions, it is not very easy for me to find something suitable.

Oh yes! If only this one were easier to get ....
Take one part Rochas Man, one part One Million, add a few
smaller parts of Le Male, Tuscan Leather, and Lalique White, and sew the
whole thing together nicely. The result is the sultry, plump sweet "sex bomb"
that hardly any young man around 24 can resist.
It's voluptuous, creamy toffee in a 84D cup size ... !!!
For many, it's dreamy! -
Unfortunately, such dreams are not very practical for everyday use.
You can really tell with this creation, especially when you spray it into your gripping hand: No matter what you touch with it, a new, musty rotten smell emerges!
Presumably, the thread that holds the beautiful bride together is an overdose
of scent enhancers. -
Without extensive testing on the skin, this can end up being quite sobering!!
Still always worth a test!

The citrusy osmanthus plays really well with the unique notes of powdered sugar and wheat. I find this to be a classic and comfortable fragrance, I often wear this when I am outside for extended amounts of time as it holds up well. I recently tried Narciso Rodriguez for Her EDT and they are strikingly similar, but I actually prefer this as it smells more complex and less animalic

This is a pretty and very feminine scent but nothing about it sticks out as particularly special to me (excluding the absolutely beautiful bottle). I really appreciate how fresh and joyful the peony is in Elysium Pour Femme and I enjoy that note quite a bit here. However, there is something about Elysium Pour Femme that feels akin to hairspray.

Nice scent that I can't imagine anyone being offended by, but I think you can find other similar scents that are similar for better price.

Of the Roja Women's sample pack this sits somewhere in the middle for me. Not my favorite but also not a dislike. It's just sort of fine.

Elysium Pour Femme is … okay. It is exactly what people say:
A bright, fruity-floral scent (but with a powdery base) that tends to lean in a shampoo-like direction. It is pleasant and unobtrusive, but surprisingly basic for a Roja fragrance. An aldehydic-sharp freshness that is nice enough, but not particularly memorable.

I’m glad I didn’t blind buy a whole bottle. The 2 ml sample was the right decision - a few wears confirmed to me that Elysium Pour Femme is perfectly fine, but nothing special or something I would prefer over other fragrances in my collection. The long longevity and the charming bottle are positive aspects.

it smelled on a hot summer day in my grandmother's garden.
This fragrance opens with fruits that harmonize very well together.
Then a multitude of different flowers joins in.
My grandmother had a large garden with fruit trees and bushes, as well as many flower beds, hence the comparison.
The base makes me think of sitting with a vanilla ice cream in hand on one of her old wooden garden chairs.
This fragrance certainly hasn't reinvented the wheel, but it is a truly lovely companion in summer.

As has been read in many statements, the expectation was high, and the fall therefore deep.

It is not a bad scent in my nose. It starts fruity, slightly citrusy/sparkling, accompanied by a lot of floral notes, and ends sweetish/slightly woody. It is rather light, bright, without much depth. If one were to be unkind, one could label it as "watery." On my skin, it has a somewhat melony quality.
A fruity scent that works for me, a light all-rounder, but also nothing new, nothing special, and therefore unfortunately not worth the price for me.

review_title: A Positive Surprise with an Inappropriate Name
review_content:
The first Orodion by Justin didn’t really impress me. However, the extremely negative reviews here on Parfumo are still hard to understand. For me, it leaned very much towards the BR540 direction, which should actually appeal to the mass taste. Since I’m not a fan of the "original" at all, I only liked the Orodion somewhat. Still, it’s a good fragrance and certainly not one that deserves a 5.5 rating.

With the right mindset, I approached the second release. Probably a very mass-appealing, rather boring fragrance for summer.

However, the notes already hinted that this cannot be a purely summer fragrance. More like autumn or winter. Small spoiler: That’s indeed the case.

First, let’s talk about the bottle and packaging. They are of really high quality and significantly better than many other niche houses. That’s already a plus point.

The plum in the fragrance pyramid particularly stands out. I immediately thought of the wonderful Arabesque, as it also contains plum, but more on that in a moment.

The fragrance indeed starts with a distinct, delicious plum note. This is enveloped by almonds and nutmeg. Sweet fruitiness describes it quite well. In the drydown, there’s soft sandalwood, which makes the fragrance very creamy. Vanilla also comes through a bit at some point, and I personally can’t directly perceive the oud, but it’s probably there and gives the whole thing a certain foundation.
Overall, one can say that with Orodion Blanc, we have a soft, creamy sweet fragrance with good fruitiness from the plum. Nothing here is overly disturbing or stands out negatively. A nice, rounded overall package.

Especially in the drydown, a clear similarity to the Arabesque is noticeable. I don’t find that bad at all, as the Arabesque is a phenomenal fragrance. Orodion Blanc is not a dupe or clone, but it still goes in that direction. So I really like it a lot.

As already suspected, this is a full autumn/winter fragrance for me, or for evenings or a date. In summer, it can be worn but isn’t necessary.

In my opinion, it’s also unisex, although it’s more suitable for mature individuals. Theoretically, due to the sweetness, it could also work for younger people if they really want to. It’s not a Tobacco Oud by Tom Ford, which clashes everywhere, but a mass-appealing yet very beautiful autumn/winter fragrance.

Longevity is completely fine at 8-10 hours. However, the Arabesque lasts longer. The sillage, on the other hand, is really very good with Orodion Blanc. You leave a reasonable but pleasant fragrance cloud behind.

For the quality of the fragrance and bottle as well as the DNA, I find the 100 € completely reasonable. Fairly, I must say that if I had to choose one, I would rather go for the Arabesque. It makes the whole experience slightly better and lasts longer. Unfortunately, there’s only the large 100ml of that, although the price per ml is roughly the same for both.

In summary, it’s a really very solid release that I didn’t expect at all. Also, the name doesn’t hint at this fragrance direction. In autumn and winter, it will definitely be used by me, and I certainly don’t regret the purchase.

I can’t really relate to Justin’s clothing style, and I don’t watch his videos, but I have to tip my hat to the Orodion Blanc. Really well done!

Orodion Blanc sounds like a distant planet. Far away from all wars, unrest, environmental disasters, deceit, and trickery. A small star that somehow pulses in the sky when you fixate on it long enough.
A creamy almond dessert, almost like a mousse. Briefly caramelized with almost unripe plums and doused with a splash of cedar sap. In a fireproof bowl, it is stirred smooth. Amber and vanilla brittle are folded in repeatedly until a creamy blend is formed. Now, right now, the bowl is hung over smoldering sandalwood, on chains of nutmeg beads. The steam from the sparkling, dense, and woody sandalwood wafts around this creamy mousse, giving off such a wonderful aroma. It is not a sweet dessert, but a creamy poem that delights your nose.
Sandalwood, just the way I like it. Although I usually approach sandalwood with some distance.
Far away from Arabesque, with which it is compared. It has a completely different scent DNA for me.
Orodion Blanc is extremely pleasant to wear and could even enrich my collection.
Thank you so much, Don, for this fragrant experience!

review_title: Pleasant Plum in a Woody Vanilla Coat
review_content: The first Orodion fragrance was purchased and found to be good. So on to release No. 2 Orodion Blanc. The scent comes in an elegant white-on-white bottle and feels high-quality. The opening begins with a warm vanilla note accompanied by roasted almond. The plum only comes to the subtle forefront for me after a few minutes and remains perceptible for a long duration, yet never intrusive. After about a quarter of an hour, a coat for the warm plum joins in, like a pleasant vanilla coat for the plum. However, for me, it’s not a summer scent as it is too sweet and too woody/spicy, but it is well-suited for autumn and the soon-to-begin winter, making it a pleasant companion.

I already bought the first Orodion, but I found it quite unpleasant. Somehow a biting smell that caused headaches. Still, I wanted to give the second fragrance a chance. The first time I sprayed it, I was really blown away! I would love to bite into this sweet oriental plum.
The problem...
Other users described the scent as vanilla with the plum in the background. I must strongly disagree with that. In the first hours, I exclusively perceive this incredibly sweet, creamy plum, and that’s where I have my criticism. I’ve been wearing the fragrance for the 3rd day now and I’ve simply gotten used to this plum bomb. My mood regarding this scent has shifted from “How awesome is this” to “Oh no, not this plum again.”
For me, it’s definitely a fragrance that is wearable. But maybe only every 2 weeks.

Recently, it has been quiet around the well-known YouTuber, and I haven’t followed him much lately. I somewhat liked his first fragrance, but I was unfortunately not convinced by the H/S for the price, although the 5.5 rating was also very harsh.
Coincidentally, I saw that he is now releasing his second fragrance, and the bottle convinced me. With the intention that if I don’t like the scent, I would return it, I placed the order. Now the fragrance arrived today, and while unpacking, I noticed again how good the bottle has turned out. The gold fits perfectly with the rest of the bottle and is very harmonious, but is the content as well?
To the much more important part, I must say that the bottle really matches the scent. At first, a very sweet plum comes at you, enveloped in powder and cream. At the beginning, it really punches you in the face; after the drydown, vanilla and sandalwood come into play, and the sweetness projects very well.

I can’t say much about the longevity and sillage yet; I still need to test it thoroughly, and that will be the decisive moment whether this fragrance is really worth the money this time. From the whole presentation and the scent, this is already a good start. Hopefully, the H/S won’t disappoint; otherwise, I will probably have to fulfill the intention I had when ordering.

(Regarding the comparison to Arabesque, I can’t say much since I don’t know the scent, but from the pyramid, it seems to resemble it.)

Last week I reported on "Arabesque | The Merchant Of Venice," and now it's time for this Orodion Blanc, which goes in a similar direction. It's not a true 1:1 twin, nor is it a really budget-friendly alternative. The price is reasonable, but unfortunately, this scent is only available in 50ml. This makes it rather expensive in terms of price per ml. Nevertheless, I can highly...

I got this fragrance about 2 years after its release, having thought about it often, and finally decided to get it. The scent opens very soft and creamy with a lovely plum note. It's very pleasant for daily wear as it makes you smell "freshly washed" in a luxurious way. The bottle is very simple and high-quality (some big brands could take a cue from this). I currently...

My second fragrance from Orodion, the Blanc. It surprised me more positively than the first fragrance from Orodion. The scent is not very sweet, rather creamy, which I really like. On my skin, the fragrance lasts a good 6-7 hours, which is sufficient. The projection is noticeably stronger at the beginning and unfortunately decreases progressively. In my opinion, the...

This scent... where should I begin. It is truly a creamy Chicomico fragrance. It is beautifully sweet, the sandalwood is well noticeable and blends nicely with the other components, but it definitely stands out and it simply smells good. I find that when you smell it, you really just feel comfortable. I associate it with a warm, woody, sweet, and also slightly almondy...

Boozy plum schnapps, a fireplace to warm up after an autumn walk. Sweet plum, cinnamon, then a smoky note follows that I know from Arabesque. At the opening, I still thought it wasn't a unisex candidate until the smoky note made its appearance in a way that was anything but bland! The nutmeg is very present here, a scent that warms in the truest sense of the word. I don't perceive the oud at all. The sweetness transitions into a smoky spiciness, a perfect scent for really cold days. However, for me, it's not a candidate for purchase; this spicy note is just too masculine for my taste.

...to blame for buying this perfume based on promotional videos and reviews. Not that I fundamentally dislike it, not at all. But more on that later. What annoys me is the publisher's portrayal, claiming he has created, quote: "a crazy scent that you've never smelled before." People, this is Oud Save the King EAU DE PARFUM 95%. The oud, which was already not...

The fragrance opens with a gentle sweetness reminiscent of dark fruits like plums, yet it remains subtle. This fruity note is complemented by a hint of vanilla that subtly refines the sweetness. Noble sandalwood provides depth and masculinity (which is not overly pronounced) but adds a certain spiciness to the perfume.

Very successful, yet specific and not suitable for every occasion.

A super beautiful creamy scent. I can really see this on women, but it is a perfect unisex fragrance, as both women and men can wear it without hesitation. The creamy vanilla that I notice all the time is wonderfully light and pleasant.
So pleasant that you can truly wear it anytime and anywhere.

Whether at work or in your free time, and even when going out to eat, you can wear this fragrance everywhere.
Sillage is quite good but not outstanding. This scent is a guaranteed blind buy if you enjoy creamy fragrances.

Bought by my husband, but I wore it more.

I was less enthusiastic about Justin's first release. However, Orodion Blanc delighted me.
Here we have a beautiful smoky, creamy, sweet plum scent. Very subtle oud (otherwise I couldn't wear it). Amber, cedarwood, vanilla... wonderful.
The notes play wonderfully together and create a really great fragrance for the cold season. It is definitely unisex and performs really well.

The bottle is quite simple, nothing wild. However, I would only buy it again if it were on sale.

Had high hopes for a fume named "Bold Citrus". Unfortunately, it's definitely not bold. Bottled Bold Citrus DOES open with a very pleasant, juicy citrus scent. It struck me more orange-y than lemon-y. However, within 5 to 10 minutes, the citrus pulls back significantly as the woody notes appear. They are mixed with, I assume, the elemi resin, giving BBC a creamy woody scent as opposed to a sharp vetiver. As it evolves further over 20 to 30 minutes, the citrus takes a definite minor role to the creamy woody scent. Quite an average scent - the same sort of quick transition numerous other freshie citrus fragrances have.

Longevity was moderate - still got whiffs around the 5 hour mark but the citrus was long gone. Projection was moderate as well. Price, even at discounters, is expensive for what it is.

After Elixir and then Absolu, I hoped Boss were on a roll here and this would be a Summer equivalent of those...

Err, not quite.

Anther very rare blind buy for me and the last I ever will, but it had just come out and the shelves in duty free were stacked with it (but it was not for sale in my country) but no tester available and the staff would not open one for that purpose.

I bought one anyway because I had my fingers crossed and it was about €60 I think.

Oops.

It smells great. For about 5-15 minutes.
Within 30 minutes, it's a skin scent.
You can overspray this stuff and it makes zero difference.

It's a really nice punchy, slightly sweet citrusy opening and I get a good chunk of mint (that no one else seems to mention) and get Torino 21 vibes (a bit) from it and it looks super funky in that bright green bottle.

But it doesn't perform.

Second bottle? No chance! I'll use the stuff up but when it's gone, it's gone.

Para mí es una fragancia la cual no he olido ninguna similar antes me recuerda a un bosque en primavera, en mi opinión es una fragancia para hombres entre 26-40 años, dado a que es muy masculina pero a la vez sexy. Si quieres cumplidos te la recomiendo, yo la usé el otro día y ya recibí varios
Nota:8/10

One could almost call the name cynical and parodic, as there is nothing bold about this new Boss, and I wouldn't call it a statement either. However, it is a completely solid citrus creamy…

“Boss Bold Citrus” doesn’t reinvent the wheel. Not Boss’s, not the office fragrance’s, not that of the lemon or the cake. Nevertheless, it combines these elements unobtrusively and well, so hardly anyone will say it smells bad. At least not the average consumer. Yet, I can well imagine that this will be too little for most perfume enthusiasts here. Too little power and twist, too little energy and uniqueness, too little shine and excitement. “Bold Citrus” is a very safe and understated blend of classic Boss DNA and lemon cake meets bathroom freshener. The latter should be read with a massive wink - but it does remind one a bit of a duck or the frog in the bathroom… Just office-dimmed. When it gets really sweaty and tight, when it gets serious, when it’s about the sausage and the roll - then “Bold Citrus” is unfortunately not the right scent. It’s enough for all warm-ups, trials, training sessions, and qualifiers. After that, it’s better to let the real men and fragrances take over.

Bottle: green but not particularly bold
Sillage: more delicate than strong
Longevity: 4-5 hours is already significantly below a normal “workday” for which the main clientele uses a “Boss” scent…

Conclusion: a solid and compact lemonizer without real weaknesses or strengths. Craftsmanship from Boss. Minimally elevated mass-produced goods. But only because I always like vetted lemons on me. Even so ordinary and standard.

Wow… the new flanker of what is probably the most successful men's perfume line of the last 2000 years has been on the market for about 3 weeks now and there is still no review…?!?!?
It may be because this scent is supposedly limited… limited (at least for now) to the duty-free shops of selected airports…. so they said (?) to the best wife of all when she had to make a stopover in Frankfurt on her business trip in mid-February. Still, it is surprising, as the crowd of influencers had almost unanimously reported on the next Boss chick.
Anyway… I’ll just do it here.
After the great Boss Bottled Absolu (which, however, doesn’t fit into the BB empire at all and would definitely achieve cult status under another name), the brand chief has hit the mark again. Although it probably won’t be celebrated in the future as much as the aforementioned little water, it will still gain many fans (if MEN can actually find it physically somewhere). In my opinion, it is the freshest Bottled variant. This is, of course, to be expected given its name… but we perfume nerds know that what’s on the label doesn’t necessarily reflect what’s inside.
At first, a lush lemon note hits the nose, so there will surely be some complainers who will equate this with a toilet cleaner; if that were the case, then it wouldn’t be so quiet in the restroom for long. At the beginning, it somehow reminds me a bit of Drakkar Noir EAU DE TOILETTE; and since I am a fan of this classic, I quite like this initial boldness. At this point, I hardly perceive the BB DNA. However, that changes after about 20 minutes. Although the subtle apple vibes are missing, patchouli and vetiver make their way forward and I feel "bottled." Meanwhile, BC performs herbaceous; but still retains the citrus note (albeit much more subdued). Later, it even becomes quite woody…. A scent journey that not many in this series are fortunate enough to experience.
After about 5 hours, the fun is already over. What a pity…
Do we need "Bold Citrus"? Hmmmm at least more than many of its siblings. Various houses also deliver woody freshies; the wheel hasn’t been reinvented here. Nevertheless, I enjoy wearing it at the moment, as it doesn’t hurt and refreshes me from morning until lunch break… very nice..

The slogan "Bold Citrus" suggests a striking or intense fragrance character, which at least in the opening phase alludes to the fresh, zesty notes of citrus fruits like lemon, lime, orange, or grapefruit. The marketers want to convey the idea of a lively and confident scent to me? Well then, let's briefly test the new limited edition citrus fragrance. The citrus fruits...

... kitchen and I am wondering whether I should dare to open my homemade preserved salt lemons for the first time? Yes, I will take the plunge. As I unscrew the lid, a fresh green scent fills my nose. I am overwhelmed; I did not expect this. I take out two slices from the jar and add them to my risotto. It was simply super delicious. When applying this fragrance, you first...

review_title: Boss Bottled Bold Citrus - a good summer fragrance
review_content:
I tested Boss Bottled Bold Citrus last week and I must say, it is really very good. At first, it smells like a lemon iced tea and it becomes softer over time for the nose, but it always retains its citrus note in the foreground.

I think Boss Bottled Bold Citrus is a perfect summer fragrance for everyday wear but also for special occasions.

All in all, I can recommend the scent to anyone who enjoys citrus fragrances.

I went in with low expectations and was pleasantly surprised because it is really a good scent for summer. You can smell a strong citrus note similar to that of Dior Homme Cologne, which doesn’t mean they smell alike, and there’s also a nice green note. It’s nothing new and it will bore many, but I think it can definitely be worn well in summer for everyday work or leisure.

The longevity is, as is typical for fresh scents, not the best, but considering it’s a citrus fragrance, it’s quite good. The sillage is also not outstanding, but it doesn’t have to be.

You can argue about the price; designer fragrances are always getting more expensive, but I find that Boss is still relatively low-priced, and you can definitely find it cheaper online.

In my opinion, this is at the top of summer designs this year.

The new Boss Bottled Bold Citrus really impressed me after the Absolute, another top fragrance from the house.
You get the lemon right at the start along with a woody accord and the classic musk feeling that radiates masculinity. All in all, I find the new Bold Citrus really successful and it will definitely continue the top path that Boss has taken.

When I first sprayed the fragrance, I was greeted by a sweet yet zesty lemon. Pleasant, but it could definitely be a bit fresher.
I didn't perceive the scent for very long, but after some time I smelled it again and wondered where this very sweet, almost heavy perfume suddenly came from. I started to doubt myself until I used the fragrance a second time and noticed that the lemon had quickly left me and the fragrance journey shifted to a rather sweet and heavy scent.
For me, this would be suitable for a little freshness kick when spraying, knowing that I'm going out in the evening. Then the scent develops appropriately for the event into a date fragrance.
However, for everyday wear, it would be too much for me. I was looking forward to a fresh lemon and unfortunately got the opposite, although only after an hour.

review_title: Boss - Lemon on the Wrong Track.
review_content:
Boss Bottled Bold Citrus - briefly BBBC - only lives up to its name in the opening.

A great opening: fresh, juicy, very strong, direct lemon. Really not subtle or extremely high quality, but well done. Fortunately, it’s also not too sweet - relatively neutral and pure. Very quickly, woods come through, and it becomes very dry and woody due to its base DNA. Here, you can recognize resin and vetiver. The lemon remains present throughout - that’s nice.

However, the drydown takes a wrong turn for me and becomes too dry, with the lemon note slipping into a chemical realm - and you unfortunately notice the price segment in which this fragrance will ultimately lie.

The Boss Bottled original DNA is very small - maybe 10 percent. I don’t see at all how many here say it’s just a Boss Bottled “with more lemon.” There’s neither apple nor cinnamon or anything like that in it. It’s a completely unique DNA. If anything, I see a good pinch of Eros with this chemical sweetness + woods and dryness.

Conclusion: 8 out of 10 in the opening, 6 out of 10 in the drydown.
It starts well and declines sharply - or simply goes in a direction that I don’t like.

Sillage and longevity are at normal Boss level.

In the end, it’s just okay, but not for retail, no way.

The well-known Boss DNA is clearly in the foreground here as well, you either like it or you don't.

To me, it smells green-fresh with a slight citrus note, appealing for both young and older audiences.

Sillage and longevity are typically improvable for Boss, with the longevity bothering me more than the sillage. With synthetic fragrances, and you can smell that here too, I prefer a more subdued sillage.

So, is everything great?

No, because honestly, it doesn't smell much different from other Hugo Boss fragrances. In a blind test, I would probably not notice a significant difference from Boss Bottled. More apple there, more green here, but overall nothing that you don't already know or have.

review_title: If you want at least one Boss Bottled, you can choose this one anytime :-)
review_content:
The regular Boss Bottled was never my thing. Too sweet and not really my style. I prefer fruity, fresh, and also aquatic scents.

By chance, I tried this one because citrus is always interesting to me.
Well, let's not kid ourselves, the citrus note that hits the nose immediately upon spraying is gone from my skin after a minute. After that, it develops into a slightly sweet, woody-warm scent. Very subtle, pleasant, and thus wearable for many.

The good thing: Ambroxan has been omitted here, so it is pleasant and wearable. (not that metallic coolness that overwhelms some and stings the nose).

I see it more for cooler days, and yes, it stands out less from the crowd, but it fits very well. It does everything right and little wrong.
Since I haven't had a Boss Bottled before, the Bold Citrus is now one that I can enjoy from time to time.
Always good when I don't want to overwhelm my surroundings or come across as too strongly attractive :D - Those who already have Bottled fragrances certainly don't need it.

review_title: I didn't like it right away
review_content:
Encouraged by numerous opinions that Nobody Knows is very similar to Ebony Wood and the promotional price at Zara, I decided to check it out and bought this perfume.
Well, let me tell you right away that I feel almost no resemblance to Ebony Wood. Even if there is some slight association with ebony wood in both perfumes, in my opinion the similarity is very distant and only at a later stage, it is certainly not a substitute, especially for a guy.
Ebony Wood is full of spices and strong clove, and leans more towards the masculine side.
In turn, in Nobody Knows there are almost no spices, I can clearly feel the tartness of blackcurrant leaves, slightly peppered and not too strong rose, and only further in the background I can feel the characteristic woody and warm atmosphere of ebony wood, but it is a different scent than Ebony Wood. The scents are a bit closer to each other in the base, but Nobody Knows does not have the expressiveness of Ebony Wood, the base is much more delicate.
Nobody Knows is fruitier, tart, much fresher and greener, although still quite heavy and although it can be considered unisex, it veers definitely towards the feminine side.
As a man, I had great reservations about wearing this fragrance and gave it to my mother. They fit a woman better.
The parameters are very decent, I could feel them clearly for 6-7 hours, the projection was quite good at first, but after an hour it was delicate.
If you're a guy, don't expect Nobody Knows to give you similar vibes to Ebony Wood.
It's a good perfume, but I recommend it mainly to women who like woody, tart, fruity and green scents. Rather for spring and warm autumn.

Edit:
After giving Nobody Knows to my mother and feeling it on her, the resemblance to Ebony Wood is nonetheless striking. I felt this scent a bit differently on myself... but I will probably repeat the tests.

review_title: A charmer who is bad at first impressions
review_content: I had never tried a Zara perfume and don't have a store near me, but kept reading about how some of their many fleeting offerings are quite good. I noticed 100ml Nobody Knows on clearance for $12.99 and was intrigued by the notes and a few reviews stating that it smelled like Gris Charnel. So, I blind bought, thinking it costs less than a burger and fries, so no big risk. The bottle is not much to look at and the atomizer feels alarmingly wobbly and flimsy, but it sprays without dribbling so far. I applied to my wrists to give it a go and the opening was not great. There was a rotten fruit note that jumped up immediately, nestled in with some garden green leaves and black pepper. It is a cacophonous introduction, like someone who has clearly not showered this morning or brushed their hair stumbling into work spilling items out of their bag and smelling of elderberry cough drops. I thought to myself "oh, no," wondering if I'm going to have to scrub this one off. I carried on with a few tasks for about 20 minutes, thankfully only catching slight whiffs now and again. I stopped to sniff again and, lo and behold, she has combed her hair and brushed her teeth! The fruit note is nearly gone, replaced by a creamy, coconutty wood, and cardamom. I sniff and sniff again and, though I wouldn't call it a twin, I can smell the comparison to Gris Charnel. It is softer, less dynamic, and sweeter, but it is there. I would almost call it a cousin of both Gris Charnel and Crystal Noir. I will be curious to see how this one performs in warmer weather. For the price, I think this is a pretty good one. Just be patient in the first few minutes and let her get herself together.

Since I already own Ebony Wood by Zara and really like it, I was immediately curious when I discovered Nobody Knows at Zara the other day. Because this one is also said to contain ebony. So I tested it right away. And yes, I immediately smelled a similarity to Ebony Wood. The same wood accord that I like so much. Nobody Knows starts off very pleasantly sweet-sour-currant-like, but the wood is already perceptible. The rose is also well recognizable and fits, in my opinion, very well with the other notes. The fragrance smells harmonious and significantly more expensive than it is. Zara releases a lot of generic and boring scents, but they also manage to create great compositions that can definitely compete with niche fragrances. This one is one of them. This special "Zara ebony note" is something you either like or you don't. I like it. Nobody Knows has fully developed after at most 30 minutes. The woody, very slightly smoky accord now dominates the EdP, and the pepper adds a nice kick. However, the rose can still be faintly smelled until the end, while the delicious currant has pretty much said goodbye quite quickly. For me, a very successful fragrance that, of course, got to come home with me.
